speechtext: The hon. member for Kamloops is rising on a point of order. I may know what it is. Ordinarily we would deal with it at the very end of Routine Proceedings and I am prepared, of course, to do that.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate there is a reason to present this point of order now as opposed to at the end of Routine Proceedings because of a meeting that is scheduled for 11 a.m.
Late yesterday the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader rose in the House and asked for unanimous consent to table the 50th report of the House management committee. One would then assume that if there was going to be a report from the committee that the committee would have met to have a report.
I want to say there is actually one way around this. The practice of the House has been for some time now that when striking the membership of committees, if there was unanimous consent by the Whips, that authority was given to the Whips to agree that the report could be tabled without going to the management committee.
However, yesterday when my friend the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader introduced the tabling initiative I indicated at that time that we had not agreed to the membership of the committee and therefore the request was withdrawn.
Later in the day the same initiative was taken when the parliamentary secretary asked again that the report be tabled. The Whips did not agree. The only way then that that could proceed would be for the House management committee to meet, agree on the membership of the committee, and then the parliamentary secretary or the chair of the committee could ask that the report be tabled. That was not done.
In other words, in one of life's many mysteries, we would table the report of a committee which never met and I do not know how that could be done.
I think we have to watch this practice because if the parliamentary secretary was presenting a report that did not reflect the decision of the committee we are getting into very dangerous territory.
I would ask that you give some thought toward considering the 50th report of the Standing Committee on House Management not receivable at least until the committee has had a chance to meet and decide upon the report.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the Whip for the New Democratic Party was seeking the floor. Perhaps it would be better to hear what he has to say before I respond, if that is all right.

speakerposition: Whip of the N.D.P.
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday I received a call when I was in a committee from the House leader's office indicating that the government had risen to present a report of the striking committee for Bill C-91.
I had submitted the name of our caucus member who was to be our representative on that committee, but it was not until I saw the Votes and Proceedings today that I saw the names of other members who are being appointed to that committee. There was no consultation with me as Whip of the New Democratic Party as to the composition of that committee. There was no meeting.
In fact after the telephone call and after the parliamentary secretary for the government House leader

November 19, 1992
Point of Order
withdrew the report of the House management committee, I spoke directly to him in the House. I advised him that I did not agree with the tabling of the report and I further advised him of the need to call a meeting of the House management committee.
When the House management committee established the procedure to provide the Whips with the ability to present reports directly to the House if a unanimous decision was made, it was done to expedite the mechanics of operating the House of Commons. It was not designed in any way to provide an opportunity for the government to do what it felt was appropriate without ensuring that it had the support of the other two Whips.
I ask that you consider this matter and as my House leader has suggested, set aside the 50th report. In addition to that, the organizational meeting of Bill C-91 has been called for eleven o'clock this morning, the same time the House management committee has been called to meet. I ask that you find a way in which to suspend the organizational meeting of the Bill C-91 committee until such time as the House management committee has been able to receive the recommendation of the membership of that committee and determine whether that is an appropriate group of individuals to be on that committee.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I understand that the Liberal Whip wishes to be heard.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I also want to say on this matter that it was only yesterday during Question Period that I submitted the names of the Official Opposition members to the committee clerk and I did not have any consultation with the other two Whips. I do not even know who the other members are. I was surprised when I saw on my office television that the striking report was being deposited unanimously.
Usually, even though we hardly ever oppose the chosen names, there is a minimum consultation and discussion so that we can strike a committee. Those are the facts I would like to present to you on this matter.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, now that no one else is rising to speak I will now endeavour to state my understanding of the circumstances.
During Routine Proceedings yesterday afternoon I did indeed table the 50th report of the Standing Committee on House Management which contained names of members from all three parties to become members of the legislative committee on Bill C-91.
This I did as a result of information that was conveyed to me during the course of Question Period that there had been the appropriate consultation among the Whips and that there had never been any difficulty from the perspective of the New Democratic Party. There had been some last minute discussions with the Liberal Party. However, I got the message that those discussions were now concluded and it was appropriate to table the report, which I then proceeded to do.
There was an intervention from the House leader of the New Democratic Party who said that the report was not in order from the perspective of his party. I subsequently had a private discussion with him in which I understood that the name of his representative had been submitted by the Whip and that it appeared to be in order. I then made some further inquiries and came to the conclusion that all was in order, that the report was properly constituted and that there had been a thorough discussion among the three Whips.
Then last evening I sought unanimous consent of the House to revert to Routine Proceedings for the purpose of receiving the motion. That consent was given by the House and I deposited the report, having earlier in the day of course deferred to the word of my friend, the hon. member of the New Democratic Party, having received earlier unanimous consent to withdraw the first deposition.
I think it is important the House understand that the practice is that the Whips never see the names submitted by the other parties. It has been standard practice since April that the Whips do not consult as a group. The report was submitted on behalf of the House management committee as the appropriate vehicle for channeling the names submitted by the Whips.
I would submit, Sir, that the report was properly deposited, that the committee is now properly constituted and ought to begin its work.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is indeed an unusual incident. I say unusual for these reasons.
November 19, 1992

Yesterday, my colleague, the House leader for the New Democratic Party and deputy leader, spoke. We have heard him again today and we have heard the Whip for the New Democratic Party. They indicated yesterday very clearly that there were some difficulties surrounding this particular issue as to the unanimous report of the striking committee.
Having said that, I think the signal was clear, the direction was clear that if one were to proceed in a positive manner obviously there would have to be meaningful consultations which would have to take place thereafter. This is the direction that the management committee has given the striking committee. That is the way it operates.
We have heard again this morning from my colleagues, the House leader of the NDP and the Whip from the Official Opposition, that those consultations did not take place. I think the parliamentary secretary is right when he says that names were given by the respective parties, but the second part of the equation in terms of consultations did not take place.
Also, in this particular incident, I do not believe the Whip from the Official Opposition signed the report normally provided by the clerk. I think he did in fact send a letter indicating the names. If one wishes to interpret that as being a form of consultation, I do not think one would be accurate.
I think that is a very clear statement of the facts. The signal was given yesterday. There have not been consultations. It has not been unanimous and I am sure that with some goodwill on the part of the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader that this report ought not to proceed as tabled yesterday.
One might ask: "How come unanimous consent was given last evening?" That in itself is quite an oddity in view of what the deputy leader and the House leader for the New Democratic Party said yesterday. He was not in the House, the Whip of that party was not in the House, the House leader of the Liberals was not here nor the Whip. I am not trying to impute motive but I suggest that this is an unusual occurrence and I would hope that the parliamentary secretary will relent in his persistence of pursuing with this report in view of the facts and the signals which have been exchanged by the respective parties.
Point of Order

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think I have identified where the problem is. In listening carefully to the words of my hon. friend, the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader, he indicated that the respective Whips had submitted the names of the representatives of the parties for the committee.
The House management committee has empowered the Whips to report directly to the House when there is unanimous agreement among them on the membership of the committee. In other words, in those many cases where there was agreement among the Whips that the composition-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: Just a moment, please. The hon. member for Kamloops made a reference. Is the hon. member reading from the motion of the committee passed some time ago with respect to the unanimous consent?

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am paraphrasing what the agreement was, and that was that where there is agreement among the Whips on the membership of the committee-that does not mean having submitted a name, but on the membership of the committee-it proceeds automatically to the House and not necessarily through the House management committee process.
The point that we are making this morning is that the membership was not agreed upon by the Whips. Normally it is, but this is one case where it was not. Names were submitted but there was no indication from the Whip of the New Democratic Party-I cannot speak for the Whip of the Liberal Party-that they had agreed to the membership of this important committee. That is the point.
While I respect the views of my hon. friend that, yes, we did submit a name, I want to simply make the case that the composition of the committee was not agreed upon by the Whips, which therefore makes it now necessary to go back to the management committee to receive its report.

subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, just to support the position made by our House leader and the Whip of the New Democratic Party, I know that we are not supposed to look into the internal operations of a committee, but there was no committee meeting to authorize this report. The parliamentary secretary for the government House leader says, well, the Whips agreed. It is evident that the Whips did not agree. In

November 19, 1992
Point of Order
communications directly with him and with each other, they did not agree on the composition of this committee.
This committee is, therefore, not struck. The House management committee did not meet. Therefore, the House management committee cannot report to this House. It does not have any authorization whatsoever to make a report when the committee itself did not meet.
The only exception to that is if the three Whips unanimously agree on the composition of a committee. Then they can authorize the chair of the House management committee to report to the House. They did not do that.
The only remedy the government had at that time, when the three Whips did not agree unanimously, was to call a meeting of the full committee, where I suspect using their majority they would have got their way. But they rushed that process. We know that they are veiy intent on getting the changes to the Patent Act through the House, but to skip the necessary requirement of having a full House management committee when they knew that there was a dispute among the Whips is unacceptable.
I think it is very important, Mr. Speaker, that not only do you not allow this report to be received and acted upon, but that instructions be issued for that committee not to start its work in one half hour's time.

subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: Before we go any further, perhaps hon. members could assist me on facts. speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will try to be as brief as possible because I truly believe that this debate belongs
in the House management committee rather than on the floor of the House, but it is here and we must deal with it here.
On April 29, 1992 the House of Commons concurred in the 28th report of the House management committee and this report dealt with standing order changes regarding legislative committees.
On May 7, 1992 the House management committee passed a report which stated: "That further to the motion adopted by the committee on June 18, 1991, the subcommittee composed of the three Whips be delegated all authority to act as striking committee pursuant to Standing Order 113, and provided that the report recommendations are unanimous it present them directly to the chairman of the committee for presentation to the House on behalf of the committee".
This allowed the striking committee to bypass the House management committee in order to table reports on the membership of legislative committees. The clerks of the House management committee needed to put in place a process whereby they could get consent on membership from the Whips and get the reports into the House.
Up until this point the Whips were able to do the same thing by submitting the names of the members from their own caucus to the clerks who would put together a list. The list would then be circulated among the Whips for their signature and then returned to the clerks. The clerks then put together a report for the chair to table.
This was thought to be a rather cumbersome process and so after the above motion was passed the clerks consulted with the Whips and decided on a new process. Again, briefly, it goes like this. The Whips submit the name of the member to sit on the committee along with the Whips' initials. The clerks can immediately put together a report for the chair of the House management committee to table.
Problems arose with this as well. The office of the New Democratic Party Whip regularly sent over names of members without the initials of the hon. New Democratic Party Whip. The clerks would send the notice back and ask for the initials. Sometimes this would take a few days. The clerks began to submit reports without the New Democratic Party Whip's initials.
November 19, 1992

At least three cases are on file with the clerks' office in which the hon. New Democratic Party Whip did not initial his submission. The reports were tabled and deemed adopted without incident. Those reports were: the 40th report, Bill C-73; the 46th report, Bill C-79; and another report which number I do not have but it was with reference to Bill C-78.
Thble clerks have told us and it is my judgment that if the committee chair feels that the committee report is in order and he or someone on his behalf tables the report it then is in order.
If the opposition raises a point of order on the matter I believe the Chair should not entertain arguments because as far as I am concerned the committee report is before the House. If the Whips are unhappy with that, I submit is a committee problem and must be dealt with within the committee.
I did have an opportunity to consult with the chair of the House management committee yesterday evening and he confirms the facts as I have outlined them. I regret that he is out of the city today and not able to be in the House, but I can assure the House that the view as I have outlined it was confirmed by him in a conversation I had with him yesterday evening.

subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT

I will hear the next hon. member, but I just want to point out to the House that there seems to be some confusion about the situation at eleven o'clock.
The information that I have is that no formal notice has gone out to hold that meeting.
My concern now is that whether it is at eleven o'clock or whether it may come back a little later, there is a point of order in front of the Chamber and in front of the Chair. I think I am going to have to deal with it unless hon. members can resolve it among themselves, which would be the best solution, but that may not be possible.
I will hear the hon. member for Thunder Bay-Atiko-kan. Unless there is something vital and new that has to be brought in-the hon. member for Saint-Leonard wants to speak-it is probably my responsibility now to reserve and see how quickly I can settle this matter, if it is appropriate for me to do so.
Point of Order

speakerposition: Whip of the N.D.P.
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT

Mr. Speaker, I want to add one key point. Yesterday I advised the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader, when he was in his seat in the House, that I did not agree to the report of the House management committee to strike Bill C-91. I indicated very clearly that the matter should be referred to the House management committee to be resolved.
Regardless of whether or not there was a signature, regardless of whatever the process was, I told the hon. member that I did not agree with the report.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the striking committee of the subcommittee of the House management committee is composed of three Whips: the government Whip, the opposition Whip and the NDP Whip.
This subcommittee was created and received power delegated from the House management committee to expedite the changes in the formation of the committees so that the subcommittee did not have to go to the House management committee to get approval before presenting the report.
With this delegation of power one thing is very clear. This report has to be unanimous. If it is not unanimous it cannot be presented to the House. It has to go to the House management committee. What is happening this morning has not happened in the past. Once the names were given by the three Whips a report was prepared and the clerk was asked to have the three Whips sign that report before putting it before the House.
As opposition Whip I was not asked to sign that report and I therefore did not sign the report. I do not think, if we look at that report, that my signature or initials are there. I heard that the NDP Whip did the same thing.
There was no meeting. Whether physically or by signature there is no agreement. This matter is to be discussed at eleven o'clock and the striking committee has to report to the House management committee and maybe we could clear it up this afternoon.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT

Routine Proceedings
I would like to think we made the case strongly that this report ought not to be considered receivable. If the Speaker were simply to rule that the report submitted, the 50th report, is not receivable, at eleven o'clock the management committee could meet and deal with the issue. If the legislative committee meeting for Bill C-91 can be put off until some time later in the day then I think things can proceed as normal.
It is important at this point that the management committee deal with this issue and the report be subsequently tabled in the House. Then the legislative committee could get on with its business.

The hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond is showing some concern. I do not want to cut him off.

Mr. Speaker, we certainly want to give you sufficient time to adjudicate on the matter but, suffice it to say, I concur with my colleagues, the House leader of the NDP and the deputy leader, that in fact the NDP Whip said no in the House of Commons yesterday.
No was said in the House of Commons by the NDP House leader; no has been said today by the opposition Whip. Those facts have to be paramount in Your Honour's decision.

subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will be very brief. At 9.30 this morning, the clerk of the legislative committee on Bill C-91 called the office of the member who would be appointed from the New Democratic Party saying that a meeting was set for 11 a.m. today in Room 536 of the Wellington Building.
We just received a call to say that meeting has been cancelled. My only concern is that things seem to be happening very quickly in the last hour. I would like to be assured that no meeting of this committee would be called until Your Honour has had a chance to report back to the House.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
The issue that I am asked to decide may very well, depending on my considerations if meetings go ahead when the Chair has been asked to determine as a consequence of interventions that have been made, the
appropriateness of the entire procedure, then I have to deal with that issue.
Naturally the better course would be that members co-operate and that there would certainly be no meeting by the legislative committee. The management committee may indeed want to meet and to discuss this matter. If that resolves it all then I would not have to make a ruling.
I must say that I am reluctant to put the Chair into the midst of all this, but I have the matter in front of me and I am going to try to deal with it. In the meantime, while I withdraw and reserve and try to help resolve this hon. members might also see if they can resolve it.
I am going to ask my Deputy Speaker to proceed with Routine Proceedings. I know that there is a question of privilege coming up later. We may ask the hon. member who is busy somewhere else at the moment to adjourn that. His place would be confirmed and the hon. member for Kamloops might want to discuss that with him.
I am going to leave the chair, reserve, and see if I can solve this issue. I would ask other hon. members to see if they can solve it before I have to.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Pursuant to Standing Order 68(2), the motion is deemed adopted.

Madam Speaker, the purpose of this bill is to amend the Parliament of Canada Act and to impose mandatory disclosure of members' expenses directly related to their parliamentary duties. Every year, not later than 30 days after October 31 and 30 days after March 31, members would provide a statement of expenses directly related to their parliamentary duties. This bill would come into effect at the beginning of the Thirty-Fifth Parliament.
The proposed legislation follows the recommendations of the sixth report of the Special Committee on the Review of the Parliament of Canada Act, tabled in this House by the hon. member for Vercheres on December 18, 1990.
Finally, the bill follows the recommendations made by the Auditor General of Canada, Mr. Denis Desautels, in his report on the audit of the House of Commons Administration, section 6, "members' expenses", submitted to the Speaker of the House in November 1991.
I also want to thank the hon. member for Terrebonne for seconding my motion to introduce this bill.

Madam Speaker, the petitioners who signed these petitions request that the CRTC regulate the use of foul and inappropriate language on radio and television.
They believe that parental efforts to raise children are often undermined by what happens on radio and television, particularly with respect to the use of language and violence. They stress that foul language is not necessary to inform or to entertain. They believe foul language is similar to violence, that it is one form of violence.
The petitioners ask for strict rules of conduct.

Madam Speaker, my second petition is with respect to education. These petitioners stress the importance of quality education in Canada to meet increased productivity and to ensure that we are competitive. They condemn the 3 per cent tax on student loans; they criticize the cuts to education via the transfer payments route; and they want accessible education for everyone.
The National Consortium of Scientific and Educational Societies is in Ottawa at this particular time making these same points.

More particularly, they deal with the violent deaths of Nina de Villiers of the Burlington area, Kristen French of St. Catharines and Carrie Pinard, a young lady who was gunned down inadvertently by young offenders while she was just minding her own business. We have seen an upsurge of violence and the hundreds of signators of this petition are very much taken aback because of this violence.
I urge the Minister of Justice to look into these petitions and that some consideration be given to them in this House. Further steps should be taken to somehow amend the Young Offenders Act so that our citizens are better protected in Canada.

Madam Speaker, I have three petitions I would like to present from citizens across the country. Almost every province is represented. These are in addition to the many thousands of signatures I previously submitted.
The petitioners are deeply concerned about the plight of refugee families in Canada. They urge the minister of immigration to issue ministers' permits for spouses and dependant children of refugee claimants who have been permitted to apply for landing from within Canada and allow them to be reunited in Canada for inland processing.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to present a petition pursuant to Standing Order 36. The petition has been certified correct as to form and content by the clerk of petitions. The petition contains some 191 signatures,

mostly from my own constituency of Kootenay West- Revelstoke, particularly from the cities of Revelstoke, Trail, Rossland, Castlegar and the villages of Montrose and Perthvale.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour and privilege to present to this House a rather large petition, certified correct by the clerk of petitions.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to have an opportunity to speak on this important issue today in the House of Commons.
I would like to point out how concerned we in the New Democratic Party are about the treatment of the Public Service of Canada by the present government. There is an enormous effort on the part of the government to brand the Public Service of Canada as having responsibility for many of the things that have gone wrong in terms of the government deficit and government programs, and this is absolutely false.
Canada has one of the finest and most dedicated public services in the world. Instead of attacking, demoralizing and blaming it for all the ills in the world, the government should support it thoroughly.
I will use a couple of quick examples of the kind of demoralisation that has gone on. The first one is the lighthouse services on the coast of British Columbia. The Liberal government attempted to de-staff the lighthouses of British Columbia, and this was then picked up by the Conservative government. It ran study after study and then attempted to implement a program to remove those lighthouse keepers. They are people who have been incredibly dedicated in isolated services and have provided a tremendous service to the people of Canada. Once in power, the government immediately went to the attack. I recall that happening in previous Parliaments when the Liberals were in power. There were enormous community fights on the coast of British Columbia to defend and keep their lighthouse services and transportation safety services. When the Liberals left power, we faced exactly the same thing with the Conservative government.
We have been through this three times, and every time the government attempts to blame these people for inefficiencies, the community rises to their defence.
In the latest round, the Conservative government came out with a proposal to de-staff lighthouse services, automate them and really downgrade their function. We had very large meetings in Prince Rupert with members of the public and members of the marine and aviation transportation communities. They told us we are making
this system far more dangerous than it already is by removing these positions.
There were meetings in Port Hardy and Campbell River. By the time the public meetings hit Campbell River, the government realized the political consequences of continuing in this vein were going to be fatal. It realized those public servants provided enormous service to the people who travel the coast of British Columbia all year round, realizing that it is a dangerous place to function and operate.
At one point, after a previous encounter, the government realized the error of its ways. It realized that to try to remove those public servants and blame them for many cost overruns and problems along that line would not wash, so it indicated it would allow those positions to continue in the Public Service. It then put out The Future Role of Lighthouses report and promised to upgrade the Public Service and those facilities. The report went through to Ottawa, hit the President of the Treasury Board, and died.
It really talked about the kind of service those people could contribute to Canadians. It is a tremendously valued and respected service. It simply asked for some support to keep those public servants on the job, doing what Canadians need the Public Service to do, and in this case it is protect their lives. It just called for some simple support, by means of a communication system, where lighthouse keepers could inform people in the marine and air transportation sectors about the local conditions around the lighthouse. This was often the only effective form of weather communication.
It also talked about adding basic weather reporting facilities so these public servants could enhance the job they do, but to date there has been absolutely nothing. The previous Liberal government and the Conservative government have each tried twice to de-staff this program, but with the public in an absolute uproar about it, it has cancelled its plans.
It is now trying to erode that service through the back door by shutting down the lighthouse at Sand Heads. We would really like to know what the consultant's report says about putting the public service staff back in that lighthouse to provide top quality safety service to the public.
I would like to hear the minister responsible for the Treasury Board stand up in the House and tell us if staff will be put back in that facility. I would like him to
November 19, 1992

guarantee the government will not try to get rid of these public servants out the back door. Public servants cannot do a decent job for Canadians unless they are given basic minimum equipment. Again we see the strangler of the money-bag of the people of Canada here in the House. I think it would be really very productive for the minister responsible for the Treasury Board to tell us very clearly if it will provide the Public Service with the tools to do the job. The public servants need communications equipment. They need weather reporting equipment, some basic weather training and a commitment to provide those services to the public. They need some basic search and rescue equipment, such as a boat and motor. They need a basic telephone. People in the regional office in British Columbia are talking about pulling telephones and just simple basic equipment out of lighthouses.
In many cases it is not just an attempt to save the taxpayers of Canada money. The people of Canada are being placed in serious danger. It just aggravates public servants attempting to do their jobs when you remove these picky little things. It breaks morale to try to discipline people through the back door for what I think are legitimate and important examples of what the Public Service is doing right now.
Quite honestly, if the government is looking at removing or replacing some of the people, there are a few folks in management in the regional and headquarter offices who could be replaced. Ultimately, it is not the public servants who need to be replaced. They are the ones who follow the directions of this government.
This government is enforcing absolutely unacceptable approaches on management for dealing with the Public Service. The government is hauling away the equipment to do the job from the Public Service and breaking the morale of the finest public servants in the world. It is attempting to blame them for the shortcomings of this government, and that will not wash.
Privatization is really causing an enormous break in morale within the Public Service. The Minister of Transport is considering a proposal from the district and regional office of the Pacific region to privatize coast guard helicopter services and coast guard search and rescue services with those helicopters. This is irresponsible and dangerous. It breaks the morale of the Public Service. It demonstrates the government has no understanding, on a day to day basis, of their job and mission
Government Orders
when they are told they can be replaced by Okanagan Helicopter and Canadian Helicopter. The government is going to turn that operation over as a lucrative plum to its friends and may even give them the equipment to boot.
It reminds me of the Bill Vander Zalms of the world who sell the public highway service of British Columbia to the private sector. It has been a complete disaster. The government gave away the land and the equipment. It just gave a great little plum to some friends out there. Public transportation infrastructure was handed over to the private sector. If that is done to the helicopter service on the coast of B.C. it would be absolutely destructive for the Public Service and for the safety of British Columbians.
On Sunday afternoon, November 22, in Campbell River there is going to be an enormous public meeting on the issue of the future of lighthouses. We are satisfied they are not going to be de-staffed at this point, but there must be a commitment to upgrade those lighthouses. We need representation at that meeting from the Ministry of Transport to tell us if it is going to protect the safety of British Columbians by upgrading those lighthouses and keeping those public servants on the job and able to do the job.
We want somebody from the Ministry of Transport at that meeting at the Labour Hall in Campbell River at 2 p.m. on Sunday, November 22, to tell us the government is going to kill this proposal to privatize coast guard helicopter services and keep those public servants behind those controls, saving the lives of British Columbians.

Madam Speaker, we had a fairly lengthy debate on this group of motions when we last met in June. As we are resuming debate after a six month absence, I thought it was important to put the rest of today's debate in context and remind the House and the public that we are meeting today to debate this important bill, again under closure. A government which has spent several million dollars developing the report for this legislation now wants debate on it concluded in less than two additional sitting days. Once again the public is denied the right to hear the merits and demerits of the government's actions and to make their own judgment.

Government Orders
Nonetheless I do not think that is too important. The vast majority of Canadians have already made then-judgments on this government and will be expressing those as soon as they get the opportunity at the ballot box.
I do want to again come back because the last few months have given a meaning to this bill and I think it is important to remind both the House and the public what is fundamental about this bill. It is not an esoteric exercise in internal organization of government. It is a bill that has a very real impact on the service Canadians get every day from their government and on the value they get for the money that goes into the Public Service.
During the referendum we heard one strong theme from Canadians, that they want a national government capable of governing this country in the interests of all Canadians. They want a national vision. They want a clear sense of direction and they want leadership from their national government in planning the future of this country.
That leadership depends on whom we elect to Parliament, but it depends even more on those people that day in and day out serve Canadians from coast to coast. The previous speaker referred to everything from the most remote lighthouse on the west coast of Canada to the most remote harbour on the east coast of Canada to the most remote outpost in northern Canada. It is Public Service employees who provide those services to Canadians and allow us to build our future together.
The other thing Canadians said during the referendum is that they are tired of confrontation. They want more co-operation. You do not get co-operation instead of confrontation with a government that insists on having confrontational relationships with its own employees as opposed to working in partnership with them, as it is encouraging the private sector to do with its employees.
You do not get co-operation instead of confrontation when you have months and months of rumours that the government is planning to cut 10 per cent of its employees at a time when more Canadians than ever before in the history of this country are unemployed and are facing Christmas and the holiday season with some pretty bleak prospects, not only for themselves but for their children's future as well.
The other thing Canadians said during the referendum is that they want leadership. They want government leadership in addressing the urgent economic situation of this country, not only the misery of five million Canadians affected by high unemployment, but the fundamental problems with our economy, the failure of this government to even understand the impact of global trends on Canada and to help Canadians prepare and plan and adjust to those changes. That kind of leadership does not come only from the benches in this House. It has to come from top to bottom in the Public Service of Canada.
We have a prosperity report that says there should be a systematic, thorough examination of governments at all levels where duplication is, where overlap is, and how efficiency can be improved. What do we have the government doing? A totally ad hoc, across the board threat of job cuts, job losses. We all know what that does. It does not save any money for Canadians, it just puts more money into the hands of the friends of the government who want to pick up that work on contract.
We have the release of the report of the International Labour Organization, a tripartite labour-management-govemment organization that is responsible for overseeing international conventions on labour relations, slamming this government for its treatment of its own employees.
It is not surprising to see the bill we have before us and have had before us for some months now from a government that fundamentally does not believe in government. It believes in getting out of government doing anything. I think the referendum showed us clearly that the attitude of government is at odds with what Canadians want. It is probably why we sat through months and months of committee hearings with the elected members of this government having virtually no comment and no discussion on the bill before us. They have sat through hours in this House equally silent, refusing even to debate the dozens of amendments that members of the opposition have put forward, motions and amendments that would improve this bill. We have not even had the courtesy of allowing minor corrections to the bill that are necessary to make it technically correct.

We have a government in power that does not understand the purpose of government. Members opposite in the governing party are not debating the amendments to this bill because they do not understand this bill, they do not understand the purpose of the amendments and they are unable to debate them on their merits.
We have a government that is bereft of ideas, that is tired and that should be replaced. All we can hope to do in the two days of debate remaining is to ensure that a very damaging bill is at least subject to public scrutiny and subject to our best attempts to have improvements made to it.
I want to comment briefly on the particular group of motions before us because they go to the heart of what is wrong with this bill. If we have had the best Public Service in the world, and we have had in this country, it is because for the better part of a century we have been committed to the principle that you do not get a job based on who you know or who your father was or who you have paid off. You get a job because you are the best person to do the job.
These motions go directly to the heart of that issue and this bill presented by the government goes directly to the heart of trying to destroy what is known as the merit principle. That is why these amendments are put forward, to say veiy clearly that you get an appointment because you are the best person for the job, not on some arbitrary standard your manager sets, not on some standard which may be described because your manager happens to like you, but because we have looked at the people who are qualified to serve the people of Canada and we have chosen the best. That is what Motion No. 16 is trying to accomplish. I urge the government to seriously consider supporting it.
A couple of subsequent amendments tried to correct what has been a misapplication of the merit principle for many decades in this country and throughout society. Let us be honest. We all know that when it comes to judging people on their ability to do the job, some people never get quite judged only on ability, but on their gender or on their colour or on the fact that they happen to have a disability. That is why we have not seen throughout society and throughout government women, aboriginal peoples, visible minorities and people with disabilities moving much below the lowest ranks.
Government Orders
The remaining motions are to ensure that measures in our hiring practices that discriminate against people on the basis of anything but ability are removed.
I urge the government at this last moment to consider supporting those amendments.

Madam Speaker, I am not pleased about the bill, but I am pleased to have a chance to speak against it.
This is Bill C-26, an act to amend the Public Service Employment Act and Public Service Staff Relations Act and other acts related to it. I want to speak particularly about the so-called merit principle that the government is bent on bringing in.
This principle would allow the Public Service Commission to appoint people on the basis of what it calls the competence of a person as measured by such standards of competence as the commission may establish. In other words, it will be favouritism. It will be division and the encouragement of mutual suspicion, non co-operation and destruction of morale.
To destroy agreed and objective systems of selection, competition and promotion clearly is done with the intent to destroy the Public Service as a public service. It is to prepare the way for total privatization of the Public Service, yet the government will not come out and openly state its intent. It knows there would be a revolt of the staff.
Revolts of staff are already brewing. My familiarity particularly is with the Canada Employment and Immigration Commission and the staff working in the Ontario region and the Toronto district.
Over the last 11 years, my constituency office has had good working relations with the staff of the Canada immigration centres in Toronto, not that there were not problems. Of course, there were problems. There were problems from the point of view of a constituent, there were problems from the point of view of my office staff and there were problems from the point of view of the immigration staff.
Nobody monopolizes all the problems, nobody is free of responsibility for this or that part of the problems. What I am talking about is that through consistent effort by my staff in the constituency office over these 11 years, they have been able to establish reasonable communica-

Government Orders
tion with their counterparts in the local immigration centres, and on the higher levels as well when necessary.
That is to say until this year. This year things have changed. Staff has been slashed. The government brags about increasing the number of immigrants to Canada. Toronto is the main destination of immigrants, especially of refugees. More than half the refugees come to the Toronto region. Perhaps it is not more than half the immigrants, but certainly a very large percentage of them. However, the government has been slashing the staff in Toronto, especially over this past year.
Immigration staff who used to have a case load of perhaps 30, 40 or 50 now have a case load of 100. One of them at the lower management level confessed to my assistant and said: "When I look at 100 cases sitting on my desk, I say that is 100 families whose life I am messing up and I cannot do anything about it". They are simply overloaded.
Recently there was a big hullabaloo over an expose on television about war criminals having been admitted to Canada from Somalia. I am told that one of those was admitted by one of the Toronto staff because he was so overloaded with work that he did not have time to check properly on that case, to ask the questions he should have asked. The staff is blamed and of course the government uses that gladly as an excuse for saying that we need nastier laws. We need to be able to exclude people on mere suspicion, as the present Bill C-86 provides.
If the officer has reason to believe that the person has done something in another country that is an offence in Canada, then he is inadmissible. "Reason to believe," in other words mere suspicion. Maybe he just does not like the colour of the person's skin and concludes therefore that the person might do something wrong in Canada.
I have had the case of a Canadian citizen from an African country, a landed immigrant, a citizen trying to bring immediate family members, pressing an immigration officer to do his duty in the matter and the immigration officer bursting out and saying: "How the hell did you get here?" The person said: "I'm a Canadian citizen". He said: "You're the ones that are causing the trouble". That person was black.
I do not know the officer who did that. Whether that is a consistent pattern with that officer of racial prejudice, I am not prepared to say. What I am prepared to say is that officers who are under unreasonable pressure of work may do things that are not normally within their character. None of us is so perfect that we can respond to the public as we ought to respond when the pressures of work become unreasonable.
I am told that currently in the staff slashing process they come to an officer and say: "How many reports can you do in a day?" He gives a number. They go to another officer: "How many reports can you do in a day?" She gives a number. After getting these numbers they say: "You are all going to have to do x number," a higher number in a day. It means they can lay off more staff and simply load impossible piles of paper work on the immigration staff.
Until the spring of this year when my office phoned or faxed to the immigration office to get a status report on the request of a constituent, it would take a matter of two or three days, half a week or at the most a week to get an answer. Now it is not unusual to go several months without getting an answer to the simple question, what is the status of this person's request? Repeated phone calls, repeated faxes do not get answers to questions.
The government has been slashing the staff and setting one staff person against another so that everyone is discouraged from co-operating. Each staff member is running scared of being laid off and is working against everyone else as often as he or she is working with everyone else. This was not the case before in the Toronto immigration offices.
Canadian citizens and Canadian permanent residents are being badly served by this change in the staff. The worst news of all is the new system of mail-in. Instead of a Toronto person going to the immigration office and saying: "I would like to sponsor my mother from the old country", or whatever, he is now told to phone in and wait for a package. "We'll mail you a package. You fill out the kit." You mail it in and then you sit and wait for an answer, which is probably to tell you did not fill it in right. Once you could get advice from the immigration officer on how to fill in the forms because the average Canadian is not an expert in immigration technicalities. Now they are shut out. They cannot get advice. They
November 19, 1992

cannot get answers. They cannot get the service of the immigration department.
That is the result of this government's plan to close down most of the immigration offices in Canada and force all people to deal by mail with a system that is incapable of doing this job by mail under the conditions that this government is enforcing. Therefore this bill is a scandal.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, since this is the first time that I speak in this debate, I would first of all like to tell this House about the admiration and respect I have for the Canadian Public Service. I am talking as President of the Treasury Board, of course, but also as a former civil servant who knows first hand whereof he speaks.

The civil service of Canada is miles ahead of the people I have heard on the opposition side in their readiness to face the challenges of the modem world. Bill C-26 does not come from outer space. It comes from vast consultations in the Public Service. Managers are also members of the Public Service. Employees are part of the Public Service. It is together with them that we have prepared this bill which provides additional flexibility to face the changing world.
The hon. member for Ottawa West said that we have to prepare Canadians for change. To do that we have to change ourselves and adapt. Did she visit Expo Innovation, the exhibition that was put together by the Public Service and various departments here in Ottawa to show the new technology they have brought to the management of this country. It was one of the proudest moments of my career as minister. They have been inventive.
All this new technology brings with it concern for their own jobs because with machines and new technology sometimes you can do more with fewer people. However, the purpose of the public service is not to guarantee employment for millions or a hundred thousand people. It is to provide the best possible service to Canadians, and the only sacred principle is to make sure that
Government Orders
Canadians get the best possible service with the resources available. They have to be imaginative and they are. I face these changes with great confidence.
The member for North Island

Powell River indicated that in our decision last year to introduce legislation on wage restraint we were punishing the civil servants. I have repeated in this House time and time again that this is not the case.
I would say that Canadians are being punished by the harsh realities of the modem world. Canadians feel the strain of a very difficult environment and the government also feels it. The government depends on the economy to have access to the resources needed to provide the services. It has had to adjust and take that into account and it has.
One of the great threats to our competitive capacity was the unit labour cost. We decided we had to do something as the manager of the largest organization in Canada to show the way. The member for Ottawa West said we had to show leadership. We have. We have been followed by many provinces and by the private sector. We have been able to reduce our unit labour cost to the extent that we had the lowest inflation rate in the western world at the present time. We are showing the way.
There was some mention that little consultation took place. If there was ever a bill presented in this House of Commons in Ottawa with so much discussion and consultation this is it. We have had 10 task forces made up of hundreds of members taken from all government departments. They had focus groups, workshops and various surveys that involved 7,600 public servants. I could go on. We had nearly one million brochures sent out to discuss our approach. The result is Bill C-26, a modem way of management.
My last remarks will be on the merit principle. Listening to the opposition, Bill C-26 is to achieve something terrible. I disagree totally with them. Merit, that is the selection of the best qualified person, will continue to apply on recruitment and on promotion. One must not forget that merit has never been an absolute concept. It has adapted to the various circumstances and social conditions throughout the years. For example, priority for appointment is given to persons facing lay-off. This is not merit. Preference is given to veterans. This is not merit. Canadian citizens, in certain instances, and local

Government Orders
residents are given preference. This is not merit. Therefore, it has never been an absolute.
Today improved service to Canadians is what the Public Service is all about and it has to be done through an efficient and effective deployment process which is a very important part of this bill. People who are being deployed have already proven themselves to be capable of performing duties at a given level of responsibility. I do not see what is gained by requiring a complete reassessment of their capabilities every time they are moved to similar jobs.
Favouritism has been mentioned. Managers are members of the Public Service. They come from the Public Service and they have to deliver the best possible service. They want to have the best people around them.
Therefore, I believe that this bill and in particular article 10 is very important as we proposed it. I also think that Bill C-26 is an example of its time.

Mr. Speaker, I feel compelled to say a few words after listening to the President of the Treasury Board outline, to quote him, the fact that the unit labour cost of the Public Service should show the way in our society, should lead the private sector. Now he says that we have the lowest inflation rate. That perhaps is what is wrong with the principles behind what the government is doing in this section of the bill and with the Public Service.
How do you judge the value of a worker who is working for the people of Canada and not to make a dollar for the people of Canada? How do you judge that?
While I was listening to the minister, as he said that improved service is the way to go and that is what this bill does, that is what the government has done for the people of Canada, I was thinking about overworked public servants in the unemployment insurance offices of our high unemployment areas in Canada: in Gander, Newfoundland; in Grand Falls, Newfoundland. There are a lot of Ganders and Grand Falls right across this country where people are overworked. They just cannot keep up with the workload.
How do you make a judgment on the fact that today, November 1992, Canada pension disability offices in this country are now taking off of one desk and putting
before the board of appeal the applications that were sent for appeal on March 1, 1992.
Let me get this straight now so that there is no cloudiness about it at all, so there is no doubt about it at all. A person who applies for Canada pension disability under appeal to the Government of Canada today and who wrote his or her appeal on March 1 or before March 1 is now having the appeal dealt with by the Public Service of Canada. March, April, May, June, July, August, September, October and now we are into November. It has been nine months. That is a record.
The minister talks about records. The Government of Canada has set a record today. Somebody who appeals Canada pension disability in this country, somebody who is in a hospital, is having Household Finance, Avco, or the Bank of Nova Scotia threatening to seize his or her property, home or car, such people are in hospital and having everything seized. They will qualify for Canada pension disability. I ask the minister not to get me wrong. They will qualify, but it takes nine months for an application of appeal to be read, to go from one desk to another desk. It is incredible, absolutely incredible.
What happens in the cases of people who are completely disabled and something has been lost like a letter from a doctor? I am not talking about 10 or 20 cases; I am talking about hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of cases right across Canada.
Thousands.

Thousands, the hon. member says. There are thousands of cases today. In nine months a record has been set. In terms of Canada pension disability a record has been set for the sick, the elderly and the disabled, people who have been injured on the job. They are losing their homes, losing their property, because the banks will not wait for an appeal. When has a bank in Canada or in any other country in the industrialized world waited for a disability insurance appeal? The Government of Canada has set a record today of nine months for that appeal to be heard.
The minister talks about efficiency. Why does it take nine months? It is because the people who had retired in the department were not replaced. Their desks are there. Their telephones are there. However they were

not replaced in the department. Now the question is: why not?
I would say it was for two main reasons. First, there has been a freeze on hiring in the Public Service. Second, the government has been attacking the problem in the very way that the minister has outlined today. He asked: "What can we do to bring down the unit labour cost?" He brought in a system whereby managers in the Public Service could not go up any higher in their salary scale. He brought in what was called performance bonuses. If they cut back in their departments they got an extra bonus at the end of the year. Pay offs for lay offs; that is what it was.
That was a part of the problem and the freeze was the other part of the problem. That is why today we have empty seats in the Public Service right across Canada. We have public servants who do not really have the desire to work overtime every day without getting paid for it, and they are drastically overworked.
The minister talks about money. We are going to hear it in the statement of the President of the Treasury Board and the Minister of Finance. The freezes will be extended and the cuts will be announced.
What did these employees get? If they did not get a salary increase over the past few years, what did they get? The minister says 3 per cent. I will tell him what they got, compared with the friends of the government, also appointed by the minister and cabinet.
They did not get an increase. They did not get an increase of $11,880 as the president of CN looks at in his range. They cannot go up to $407,880 as the chief executive officer of CN can today. They do not qualify for a potential bonus of $101,970 this year, and the minister speaks about 3 per cent. It is not only him.
Let us look at Canada Post. How much did the salary of its head go up this financial year? It went up $9,300 this financial year, with a potential bonus to the head of Canada Post this year of $79,800 just before Christmas. The minister did not talk about that.
Using the merit principle of unit labour cost, by what logic does the minister let the head of Canadian National qualify for a potential bonus? That is over and above his salary which can go up to $407,880 this year. On top of that he can get $101,970 in a bonus. What performance

do they judge for him? Is it the number of railway tracks he closes down?

That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 15 by striking out line 20 at

She said: Mr. Speaker, I do not want to speak at length on this single motion. Again it goes to the heart of the merit principle and whether the fundamental process in hiring, promoting and appointing people within the Public Service is based on their qualifications in order of priority or not.
The eligibility lists are established to ensure that where there is a number of positions requiring the same qualifications, the most qualified person gets appointed first. The second most qualified gets appointed next and so on down the line until the positions are filled.
There is another fundamental issue, however. This bill like many others that have come before this House in the last few years establishes a process of regulation instead of legislation. What should clearly be spelled out in legislation to protect people's rights or to allow people to know the law is more and more frequently, we are finding, being left to the discretion of the government to establish regulations. This is another such section.
The legislation right now is very clear on how an eligibility list is established and on how it is to be used. That is in the legislation. The government's bill now proposes to undermine the purpose of the eligibility list and, further, to say that regulations of the Public Service Commission will determine how the lists are made and how they are applied.
This is a further erosion of the merit principle and its protection in the Public Service Employment Act. This amendment reinstates the current definition of an eligi-

Motion No. 31
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 19 by striking out line 2 at page 11 and substituting the following therefor:
"specified period, except where the person has been appointed for one or more terms totalling one year or more to the position that the person occupied at the time the person was laid off."
She said: Mr. Speaker, just speaking again briefly to my Motions Nos. 27 and 31 and referring briefly to the motion of the member for Kingston and the Islands, one of the things that we in the opposition stressed during the committee hearings and during debate in this House is the issue of accountability.
If managers are to be given more responsibility, they must be given more accountability. Notwithstanding frequent requests to the President of the Treasury Board and to senior officials during the hearings, none of them has been able to point out any section or any wording in the act that increases accountability.
This is a public corporation. It is not a private corporation where accountability is the bottom line. Accountability is to the elected representatives of the people of Canada. It is desperately missing from this bill.
Motion No. 27 is a good example. It deletes the right to appeal against an appointment except where it can be established that an appointment was not made on merit. The ability to appeal, the ability to have some independent review of this new discretion managers are to be given is curtailed at every step of this bill. That means there is no power to oversee whether this new responsibility is being exercised responsibly.
Motion No. 27 simply seeks to delete those sections which limit the right of an employee to appeal an appointment. It ensures that the Public Service Commission, which is the guardian of the merit principle, has not only an opportunity but an obligation to review appointments, to ensure that they have been properly carried out. Without that review, the Canadian public has no assurance that their Public Service is not becoming a hotbed and a nest of appointments by favouritism.
I am not sure why these motions are grouped, frankly, because Motion No. 31 is on quite a distinct subject. However, what Motion No. 31 does is endeavour to ensure that term employees are covered by the work force adjustment policy. Throughout the Public Service there has been an abuse of term employees. The vast majority of those term employees are women or they are people with disabilities who are hired to meet a target. They are on for a few months and then they are extended for a few months, and then they are extended for a few
November 19, 1992

months, and then they are extended for a few months. Many of them have been in the Public Service for periods approaching five years without ever having established any rights as employees or any security.
To me, that is an abuse of a mechanism that should be there to meet short-term needs. It is an abuse of people who are performing a full-time job on an ongoing basis but are not allowed to have any of the benefits of that service.
What this motion does is ensure that where work is contracted out, term employees who have been there for an extended period of time have the same protection as indeterminate employees. They have been working beside each other, doing the same work, performing the same service for Canadians. They should be entitled to the same rights of protection when their work is contracted out.
I am going to refer very briefly to Motion No. 29. Essentially this motion of my colleague is attempting to deal with the situation that has been outstanding for nearly a decade. For nine years the committee on scrutiny of regulations has criticized the appeal procedures, the investigation procedures of the Public Service Commission. In reports to this House, it has recommended regulations that would ensure fairness and due process in appeals held by the Public Service Commission. For nine years the Public Service Commission has stalled on implementing those regulations for whatever reason I do not know, but I have seen horrifying examples of people denied due process to even know the information on which their appeal should be considered to have an opportunity to respond and to have time to prepare their case.
This very comprehensive motion from my colleague is intended to finally get this House to take action if the Public Service Commission will not, despite unanimous reports from an all-party committee to this House on numerous occasions.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to say just a few words to address some of the very legitimate concerns expressed by the member for Ottawa West.
On Motion No. 27 in particular, we have legal counsel which indicated that removal of this section in its entirety could effectively remove any right to appeal. There is
Government Orders
also corrective action and obviously this is not what is being sought.
On the lay-off rights of term employees, it is a fact that the provision in the bill that denies lay-off rights to term employees is intended to protect the continuing employment of career public servants. The term employees by definition are hired for specified periods and should have no expectation of continuing employment in the Public Service. That is what the definition is all about.
They have been excluded from lay-off rights since 1977. For example in some cases, term employees are hired for recurring periods of more than one year in one job. This often occurs precisely because the ongoing nature of the work is in doubt. Term employees are hired specifically in order that no commitment to indeterminate employment be made.
On accountability to Parliament, in particular the Public Service Commission and all its annual reports on all matters related to staffing and other matters within its jurisdiction, the President of the Treasury Board reports specifically on employment equity as required under the Financial Administration Act. The President of the Treasury Board is also answerable to Parliament. The head of the Public Service, the Clerk, reports annually to the Prime Minister on the state of the Public Service and the report is brought to Parliament. The various acts place many obligations on the agencies which are answerable to Parliament.
The accountability is there. The hon. member should find some comfort in that.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that I got to make my speech after hearing the rather feeble attempts of the minister to explain away these amendments. Frankly, he has ignored the point of the amendments. I urge him to get his legal advisers in the lobby and speak to them again because they are getting him in a position where he is getting himself in difficulty in the House. First of all, he said that Motion No. 27 moved by my colleague will take away a right of appeal. The right of appeal is granted by subsection 21(1) already. It is not taking it away. What it deals with is appeals from decisions of boards appointed under subsection 21(1) which deal with the appeal. They are saying that those boards' appeals can only be appealed on the ground that the measures taken did not

Government Orders
result in the selection for appointment according to merit. In other words, this section that my colleague has moved to be deleted takes away the restriction on the kind of appeals that can be launched. For him to suggest that his legal advisers have told him that this takes away the right of appeal altogether, as I say, his legal advisers are giving him bum advice and I would suggest he replace them quickly.
Second, Motion No. 29 which I have moved is in response to very specific recommendations made by a joint parliamentary committee of the Senate and the House of Commons. I do not have a copy of the report here with me, but the report was made in either 1986 or 1987, and possibly as late as 1988. There was a request for a response from the Public Service Commission and that response was tabled in this House immediately before the election in 1988.1 think it was the last day of the session. That is how responsive the Public Service Commission is to reports and how accountable it is to this House and to the Senate. There was no opportunity for any input by this House on that report before the election was called.
Basically what the Public Service Commission told the standing joint committee to do was "get stuffed". I do not agree with that kind of accountability, and neither should the minister. He should either insist that the Public Service Commission comply with the report of the committee, to whom it is responsible, or get out of office. Its members are obviously unfit to hold office in the Public Service Commission if they think they can continually thumb their nose at a parliamentary committee when they are charged under their act of being responsible to Parliament.
This committee was acting as the agent of this House and of the Senate. It was a joint appointment, it was a unanimous report of that committee, and the Public Service Commission in effect said to the committee: "We don't care what you think, we know better. We know that public servants don't need rights when they launch appeals. We know that we can allow the Public Service Commission, us, to decide what they should see and what they should not see when they launch an appeal. We will decide, for example, that they won't see any reports made in respect of their candidacy. We will
decide whether information regarding the status of the candidate in the competition should be seen by the appellant". That is the position the commission is taking.
No other public body exercises such Draconian jurisdiction over appellants before it. Under our rules of natural justice, an appellant would do better than they do before the Public Service Commission. Appellants are put through the hoops, they are told they are not allowed to see material that in any other public board they would be allowed to see as part of the appeal process. I invite the minister, who really is impartial in this-this is a dispute between the commission and Parliament-to look at these amendments again and ask if these amendments are not acceptable. Why should we not require the Public Service Commission to disclose these facts to appellants so that they can properly prepare themselves for an appeal? That is all this is asking for.
The minister surely has no interest in the outcome of this as long as the thing is conducted fairly. As minister, it is his duty to see that the hearing is conducted in a fair manner for all parties concerned. Surely it is fair that an appellant have access to the books and records that the commission has when he or she is launching an appeal. Surely those records should be made available. This amendment requires that. That is all it requires.
The minister, as the Queen's representative and as the Queen's adviser, must recognize that the Queen as fountainhead of all justice in our country and under our Constitution must be seen to act fairly and justly to all her subjects including those who make an appeal to the Public Service Commission because they feel they have been unfairly treated in the selection process.
I know that the President of the Treasury Board is an eminently fair man. He would not want to see Her Majesty's subjects deprived of any rights they should be able to exercise. This amendment only clarifies those rights, strengthens those rights, and in fact gives them rights which a hard-nosed and frankly irresponsible Public Service Commission refuses to give by regulation to these people. It says we will make the decision on an individual and ad hoc basis. It is not good enough and the minister knows it is not good enough. As a minister who has some interest in justice and fairness on behalf of the Queen and on behalf of all his colleagues in the cabinet,
November 19, 1992

he will want to see that this kind of amendment is put forward.
I see the Minister of Labour is here today. He knows that in appeals to the Canada Labour Relations Board, this kind of manifest unfairness would not be permitted. The rules of the labour board are quite specific. They grant rights to the parties before the board to see the documentation.
He would be shocked, horrified, if he went to the Public Service Commission and found out how much of this information is withheld by the commission. He would be equally shocked if he had read the report of the standing joint committee of the Senate and House of Commons which studied the issue and made specific recommendations for amendments exactly along the lines I have included in this amendment. He would be doubly shocked if he had heard the response of the Public Service Commission saying they knew better than the committee and would ignore the committee. He would not tolerate this.
Surely he can implore his colleague, the President of the Treasury Board, to come up with something a little fairer and agree to this amendment.
