speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is important when we are looking at these motions and particularly Motion No. 33 to appreciate the fact that the ability of the department to deploy workers is another central component to Bill C-26. Because the government is seeking the ability to lay-off workers by contracting out their jobs, it has moved yet again to get around a ruling of the courts by changing the powers of managers to deploy or transfer workers.
The government is seeking to add flexibility to the process of moving workers within and through various classifications, but it is doing so in such a way that it violates the merit principle and the rights of the workers.
Again we see in this clause the principle that if you circumvent the law and get caught, you change the law. It is as simple as that. That is the attitude of this government. What it is planning through this clause and the reason we have moved this motion, is the unfettered right to deploy workers as in the instance of the modification of the merit principle. It would allow managers to groom their favourites by appointing them to positions which would give them an advantage not available to other workers.
Combine that with the new classification system envisioned by the PS 2000 task force and this right to deploy means that a great many workers will be seen simply as movable pieces in a huge puzzle, being moved without competition or right of appeal. Just envision a huge chess board with workers in the public sector on that board and being moved strategically at the will of the game player but with no say about where, when or how one is moved.
Government Orders
The assurances of government spokespersons, and I am sure we will hear from the minister following my speech-

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Do not count on it.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
I would be just as pleased if he did not respond, but I suspect he does not agree with me on this issue.
The assurances of the government spokespersons before the committee that workers would only be deployed with their agreement rings very hollow. All sorts of means of coercion can be used, and no doubt will be used, to encourage workers to accept deployments.
If anybody is unclear about what deployments are, deployments mean employees are moved from one position to another. It means they could be moving from Quebec to Alberta. It means they could be moving from British Columbia to Ottawa. It means they could be moving from Ottawa to Newfoundland. That is what deployment means. It also means that they could be moving within departments.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Or from the government bench to the opposition bench.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
Yes, there would be quite a shuffle with the government moving to the third party and the New Democrats becoming government and the Liberals remaining where they are.
I do not want to trivialize this very important part of the legislation by getting into an exchange with my colleagues. It is absolutely critical that more than ever the career-passive employees in the government service will be subject to the discretion of managers. The manager will decide who gets deployed where and because of this clause in the legislation the worker will have to accept a deployment.
The minister tells us that is not true. The minister will say that it is up to the employee who has the right to say no. Then what happens? There is no provision in the future for protection for the workers, so the worker says no. Does he or she ever get promoted again? Probably not. When he or she finds a position where the deployment would be useful to his or her career path, does that worker have the opportunity to ask for or move to deployment? The worker may have the opportunity to

Government Orders
ask for it, but will he or she get it? Probably not, depending on the manager.
We have ourselves a situation where it is one more opportunity for there to be disagreement between a worker and the employer and the employee to be penalized.
No one here wants to hinder the effective and efficient functioning of the Public Service, but if the ability of managers to deploy workers in order to enhance the delivery of programs and services is desired, this must be done with appropriate safeguards.
Therefore, this amendment recognizes that a deployment mechanism can assist, not hinder, the effective functioning of the Public Service. However, it must be done within the guidelines explicitly spelled out in the act. Deployments must be made to the benefit of the worker and the demonstrated needs, not the wilful needs, of the department or agency.
I have illustrated how critical it is that the government agree to Motion No. 33.1 am sure the minister, being a reasonable and thoughtful man, having listened to me carefully, will consider the motion as being fair and reasonable.
I would like to touch on another of the motions we are covering in this grouping, and that is Motion No. 34. The motion expands the grounds under which a worker can appeal a deployment. That is very critical, building on what I said before about the ability of managers to have discretion to act upon favouritism, to not like a worker for one reason or another and, because we are all human, let that interfere with his or her operation of a work place. It is very critical we have those expanded grounds upon which a person can appeal a deployment.
There must be a wide-ranging ability to appeal without these restrictions in the legislation. I am not denigrating management in the Public Service, but we have documented instances of managers who have been misguided, for whatever reason. It is absolutely critical to safeguard and even avoid having managers tempted to practise favouritism. All of the amendments in this section should be passed.
I would urge the minister to support both my amendment and the Liberal amendments under the section of deployment. We all know he is a fair and reasonable man and will look at these amendments very carefully.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to assure the hon. member that not only is the minister fair and reasonable, but so are several of the other members on this side.
I had the privilege, earlier this year, of spending many hours in committee with the hon. member who has just spoken. We did not agree on the process nor on the final result of how we wanted to accomplish something, but we did agree on many things. We agreed we have a good civil service in Canada and we want the best possible people working in it.
There were debates from time to time, and one of my concerns was that when someone goes into management, he automatically loses all of the advantages and strengths he had as an employee. I do not think we can automatically say all employees are good and all managers are bad.
I want to go on the record as saying I know very many people who work for the federal civil service. They are good, hard-working, dedicated people. I know a lot of managers in our civil service who are also good, competent, qualified people.
I can draw an analogy to our position here. I have a teenage son who told me prior to my being elected everyone thought I was the perfect person for the job. I was approachable, hard working and dedicated. Immediately after my election I became a politician. I was associated with politicians and that attributed certain motives to me I did not necessarily have.
We have to be very careful when we are talking about the civil service that we do not ascribe motives to them they do not have. We have to recognize we have good, competent, qualified people working at all levels of our federal civil service. There may be one or two bad apples in the barrel, but we should not paint them all with the same brush.
We are talking about deployment. The hon. member who just spoke asked the minister to be reasonable. I think the bill and what is presented in it is reasonable.
Bill C-26 proposes that deputy heads be given statutory authority to deploy their employees, subject of course
November 19, 1992

to direction from the Treasury Board, to ensure servicewide considerations are taken into account. With the changes in the bill, deputy heads are going to have more flexibility to move employees to new positions with their consent. That is an order to the operational requirements, to encourage career development and provide compassionate grounds. I am sure the hon. member would agree these are all valid and worth while reasons.
Deployment is not a new concept. It is very similar to what most public servants know as lateral transfers. In 1991 alone there were some 25,000 lateral transfers in the Public Service. They amounted to more than 25 per cent of all internal appointments. It is a widely used staffing tool.
However, with the proposals there are some significant differences.
Unlike lateral transfers, deployments will not be appointments made by the Public Service Commission, but will result from decisions made by deputy heads with an employee's agreement.
This will enable deputies to move employees quickly for many reasons, including changing priorities or workloads; employee career interests and aspirations; the future requirements of the department for certain skills which can be developed in-house; the developmental needs of employment equity group members and the need to address unique situations compassionately.
For example, we may have a requirement to move an employee to be near special medical facilities. These are realities Public Service managers face every day, yet under the current legislation it is difficult to address them. The changes in this bill will give them that authority.
With deployment, the government is providing managers with a flexible staffing tool to allow them to move their employees quickly and efficiently as required. At the same time it ensures the very legitimate interests of employees are taken into consideration. Thus there is provision for employees to give consent to a deployment, and there is a recourse process which provides for independent review of the deployment consideration and decision.
Government Orders
Indeed, this balance is a key feature of much of what the government is proposing in Bill C-26 with management flexibility on the one hand balanced with consideration for employee concerns on the other.
During the committee hearings on Bill C-26, there was a good deal of discussion by witnesses and committee members about some of the features of deployment being proposed. I want to take just a few moments to address some of them.
Concerns were expressed that in making deployment, the deputy head will not be required to make a selection according to merit. This does not mean deputy heads can or will deploy incompetent persons as some witnesses suggested.
We must remember, an employee being deployed has already been qualified by the Public Service Commission for that particular level of responsibility. Little is gained by requiring a complete re-examination of the employee's qualifications or requiring him or her to be compared again to all other potential candidates.
In making their selections for deployment, deputy heads will not be required to apply all the prescriptive and procedural rules of the Public Service employment that apply to appointments.
May I remind hon. members we are not speaking here about recruitment or promotional appointments, which will continue to require selection according to merit. What about jobs at the same level with essentially the same or similar salary, benefits, conditions and duties?
We need to remember public service managers are under increasing pressure to improve the quality and volume of services they provide to the public. They are being asked to do this with increasingly tight resources and have up until now responded very well to that challenge. Managers know full well they cannot improve services without competent and well-trained employees.
The deployment provisions of Bill C-26 will allow employees to benefit from new experiences and give them the opportunity to gain new skills and training. This is critical to maintaining the professional and high quality federal Public Service we are striving to maintain.

Government Orders
Another major concern expressed by some of the witnesses was the view that some public service managers will use the deployment authority to arbitrarily move employees, favour friends and harass enemies. Their solution is statutory provisions to regulate the manager's behaviour and decision making.
I cannot support that view, nor would my colleagues I am sure. Public service managers as a group are not arbitrary. They are not unfair and do not lack good judgment. There may be mistakes made, but in an organization as large as ours with 218,000 employees and some 100,000 staffing positions a year, mistakes are inevitable.
That is what the recourse process is designed to find and resolve. That is why the Treasury Board will monitor and audit departmental deployment activities. The solution is not to limit the scope of action and flexibility of all managers for the sake of a relatively few mistakes that will be made.
The solution is not to tie the hands of managers and limit completely their authority to respond to organizational requirements. Rather, we need to ensure managers are well trained and understand the principles and values that should guide deployment decisions. We need to correct errors when they occur, and hold managers accountable for their decisions.
I have mentioned that deployment is not a new concept. It is commonly used in many jurisdictions. For many years in the Public Service, transfers or deployments, as they are now called, were treated as simple, routine, administrative matters. This did not appear to cause any great difficulty or concern.
With this flexibility, Canada managed to build a Public Service acknowledged to be one of the best in the world.
Let us continue to achieve this level of professionalism and competence. It is in the interest of all Canadians.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):

Mr. Speaker, the amendment I moved is part of this group of amendments and is similar to the one I moved before.
I was delighted to hear the hon. member for Red Deer's speech. I listened to it quite closely. I am prepared to concede many of the points in his speech. I am prepared to concede, for the purposes of my arguments today, that what the government is doing by making this transfer of powers to managers in the Public Service may be satisfactory. Let us assume for this purpose it is.
It is still fair, and he must agree it would be fair if there is a problem, if there is an appeal from a decision one of these managers has made, the person hearing the appeal ought to ensure the hearing is conducted in a fair and reasonable way. My amendment seeks to ensure that fact.
My amendment does not interfere with the discretion of the persons making the decisions on transfers and so on. It ensures that when there is an appeal from a decision that has been made, the appeal is conducted in a fair way.
Unfortunately, I suspect my amendment is in trouble. Given the voice vote we had awhile ago, I sense the government is going to vote against my earlier amendment. The new amendment we are debating now, No. 42, is contingent on that earlier one passing. If it gets defeated, the meaning of my subsequent amendment will be lost.
This amendment seeks to import to the appeal process, in the case of deployments, the same rules that should apply in the case of appointments. The rules I have recommended are not ones I thought up myself. I do not claim credit of authorship. These rules were drafted by an all-party committee of both Houses of Parliament on which members opposite had a majority. The members of that committee agreed there were fair and reasonable means of requiring disclosure and conducting a hearing. That is what the committee thought up.
The committee was composed of all parties, but was dominated by Conservatives. In other words, the President of the Treasury Board's own colleagues all agreed these kinds of measures were appropriate and recommended them to the Public Service Commission.
I see he is here and has not yet moved to speak on these rules. My last speech did not even provoke him to any comment. He simply hung behind the comments of his legal advisors. I hoped he was going to stand up and tell us he had fired them already because they clearly have given him bad advice. I would not take their advice on an issue like this if they gave me the advice he cited earlier. Maybe he misrepresented what they said, I do
November 19, 1992

not know. If he did not, it was terrible advice and he should stand up and agree that the amendments proposed here are all in accordance with the rules of natural justice. There is nothing shocking. There is nothing earth shattering in anything that was proposed in that list of amendments the board might reasonably ensure appellants have in their hands when they do an appeal. In fact, all of them have been recommended by a standing joint committee of the Senate and the House of Commons.
I should also say the committee that made this unanimous recommendation did it before the last election in 1988. The representation of the opposition on those committees must have been miniscule, because the government had such a huge majority in this House. Three-quarters of the members of the committee must have been its own backbenchers. I do not understand why it would ignore the wishes of its own party members.
The hon. member for Red Deer says there are lots of reasonable people on his side of the House. Let us see them show their reason and stand up and support these amendments on the vote. Let us see some evidence of reason. It is fine to stand up and make pious speeches that must have been written by somebody working for the minister or in the department of the Treasury Board because it was so one-sided.
Let us assume the member believed every word he uttered. I am quite prepared to believe that. Then let us have them show some reason. The easy way to do that is to support these very reasonable amendments. He could either go to the minister and urge the minister to repent and change his view and support these things, or stand up on his own with his colleagues, the group of them that he says are so reasonable over there, and show their reason and support these amendments. Let us vote them through, fix this bill, and generally treat our public servants fairly.
Surely he would agree that if the deployment is to take place, the person making the decision has to act reasonably. If there is an appeal and it is shown that the person has acted unreasonably, the decision can be overturned. The appeal process is already there. What the amendments seek to do is ensure that the appeal is conducted in a fair and reasonable way. Certainly he must agree that that is a reasonable way to start. Surely he does not
Government Orders
think the person making the decision on the appeal should behave arbitrarily or should deprive the person making the appeal of information that the person reasonably needs to proceed with the appeal. Surely he does not think that.
He, I accept, might be like the minister, fair and reasonable. Yet the minister will not respond to these amendments in a meaningful way. He tells us that his legal advisers think that they are unnecessary, or that they take away rights.
I say to the hon. member: read the amendments. I do not know whether the hon. member is a lawyer or not, but he can read this and I am sure that he would disagree with the advice that the minister has been given. Mr. Speaker, this bill is a basic change in the philosophy of government relative to the Public Service. It is a move from service to the public to something which is maybe closer to no service unless you can find the right place to get that service.
I speak this way because I find, as my colleague from Trinity-Spadina indicated earlier, that in several of the departments across the country action has already been taken to move people to change the structure of the civil service so that those parts of the country which are being most affected will not get the kind of service they had in the past.
The example used by my colleague from Trinity-Spadina was immigration. We have been told that there is going to be a change in the immigration structure, that instead of having people dealing with people, in the future the department of immigration will have a mail-in service for application, a reply by mail, or a 1-800 number which will get you not a person, but an answering service and it will indicate that if you want an application to press number 3 and there are no people so there is no use pressing number 8.

November 19, 1992
Government Orders
In each case what is being attempted is to move the whole of the civil service away from dealing with people and move it closer, as the minister says, to a modem method of management which has no people in it. Service to the public of Canada has been by a civif service that has been well trained and well motivated to provide that service.
What this and the ability of these particular motions do-and I hope they work well and that they accept the amendments-is to give the government the power to deploy people so that they can close down places like Prince Albert which has an immigration centre, Saskatoon which has an immigration centre, Regina which has an immigration centre. These will be closed down. If you want some service you will go to three places: Vancouver, Toronto or Montreal. Otherwise the service will not be available under any circumstances.
If you or one of your constituents wants to sponsor an immigrant, they call the 800 number, find out where to get an application, send in the application and then it will be sent back because it was not filled in properly because there was nobody around to help or to indicate how to fill it in.
All of these services which have been part of the great civil service of Canada, the service that has been provided to the Canadian people, are being eliminated gradually and in these particular clauses-let us hope they work well-is an opportunity or a method by which the government can close down certain departments or parts of departments in different parts of the country.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Come to Ontario and see what they are doing there.

The further I can stay away from Toronto the better and Ottawa is not so good either.
I believe the member for Gander-Grand Falls indicated it took a long time to get any kind of service in certain areas. If you eliminate the people in these areas it is going to take longer still.
If the member wants a good example he should try the process of getting a pension through veterans affairs. To go through all six stages of the process of getting a veterans affairs pension takes an average of six years. That means some of them take much longer than that
and by that time the veteran has passed on so you do not have to worry about it.
The more we depend upon machines and the less we depend upon people to give us the kind of service we want, the longer it is going to take and the more ineffective-I am not going to say less efficient-but the less effective it is going to be.
The ability in these particular clauses which allow the government to deploy people from one area to another, to move people without necessarily taking into account the wishes of the employee allows it to do things with the civil service which will give less efficient, less effective and less valuable service to the people of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak today on a bill that greatly affects Canadians and especially residents of the national capital region, in particular my constituents in Carleton-Gloucester.
As we well know, the Public Service has more than 220,000 employees in all throughout Canada. A common misunderstanding, though, is that all public servants live here in the national capital region, although we know very well that maybe 25 to 27 per cent of them are in the national capital region, but most public servants are spread all across the country according to local needs. Their number in any province is generally more or less proportional to that province's share of the total population.
As we say on both sides of this House, our public servants do an outstanding job. Public servants are there to implement the laws of the land. Public servants are there to ensure that the laws passed by the Parliament of Canada are applied and enforced. Public servants are there to serve the community, to serve Canadians, to make our quality of life better all the time.
The last time the laws affecting the federal Public Service were thoroughly examined was in 1967. We now have a new bill. I congratulate the President of the Treasury Board on presenting a very worth while bill to improve the operation of the Public Service. I was pleased and honoured to be on the committee that studied the bill. For weeks and even months, we studied this bill clause by clause. The bill is a good idea. It goes in the right direction. However, at some point one would think that the Public Service should be treated like a private enterprise, according to what the government says.
November 19, 1992

I sincerely believe that public servants are really different from workers in private industry. Government does not operate in the same way as private industry. Private industry must not only provide a service to the public but it must also make a profit. The public service, that is the government, is there to serve the community. We must help the community. Sometimes we also need regulations to ensure that things are done correctly. That is the case, for example, with inspections.
Nevertheless, even with all the esteem I have for the President of the Treasury Board, I believe that he is making a monumental mistake by not listening to the opposition members who proposed some real amendments to the bill.
I was surprised to see that the minister refused or turned a deaf ear to the suggestions and comments of my colleague from Kingston and the Islands, who challenged him, saying that he thinks some laws-and I recognize the member from Kingston and the Islands as a legal authority. We know that he was a lawyer of high standing in Kingston. He challenged the President of the Treasury Board by saying that his bill contained serious legal errors in the amendments it proposed. This does not go against the comments and statements the minister received from lawyers in his own department or from other government departments.
I was surprised to see the President of the Treasury Board, who is usually not at a loss for words, remain silent when challenged by my colleague.
We talk about deployment. In general, it is a good idea. I am sure that some public servants want a deployment. It opens new horizons for them and public servants want to serve the public. They are good public servants in the proper sense of the word who sometimes want transfers so that they can better serve Canadians or perhaps they find new employment opportunities that are interesting and meet their aspirations. [DOT]
We often see managers who are keen on having a terrific team. That is worth while, putting together a team that is effective and efficient in the way it provides services to the public. Managers who always tiy to have a terrific team are to be commended. In fact, most people are like that. I am sure that our Public Service will keep improving, if this attitude or culture is encouraged.
Government Orders
However, if a manager has the right to be authoritarian in the case of deployment and can ignore eligibility criteria and people's qualifications and bilingualism, for instance or merit, there is always a risk of abuse. That is why I deplore the fact that the President of the Treasury Board will not listen to the suggestions made by the Liberal Party.
Our amendments are intended to prevent abuse, favouritism, nepotism and prejudice of a linguistic, racial or even sexual nature. For instance, a male manager might not want any female employees because he is prejudiced against women. Occasionally, married women who have children leave their jobs for a certain period, which may not be well received by certain managers, and I would call this prejudice on their part.
With this mechanism an employee would be able to protest and appeal in the case of unfair deployment arising from favouritism, nepotism or prejudice. We need a mechanism to protect public servants against managers or rather certain managers-fortunately they are a minority-who occasionally tend towards favouritism, nepotism or, as I said before, prejudice of a linguistic, racial or sexual nature.
In concluding, I would ask the President of the Treasury Board to respond to my colleague's challenge.

Mr. Speaker, I would first like to say to both the member for Carleton-Gloucester and the member for Kingston and the Islands that there is no disagreement on the objectives for equity, fairness and sound management. What I would tell them to begin with on transfers is this: The reason that I was slow to speak up or less spontaneous, perhaps, is that this issue was debated at length, inside and out, I believe, for hours on end in committee meetings and that all those points which were raised were covered in extensive major discussions.
What I have some difficulty with is that since there may be abuses, which I do not deny, we should not, for fear of abuses or improprieties, make the system rigid. We should try to find a way to address the legitimate concerns of my colleagues opposite, but perhaps in a more flexible way. I would say, for example, that Motion No. 33 now being debated would require Treasury Board

November 19, 1992
Government Orders
to include in the act valid reasons for transfers in the directives addressed to deputy heads.
Obviously, when Treasury Board sets personnel policies, it specifies the objectives being pursued. Of course, it will take care to tell managers that they can transfer employees for professional development, for operational reasons or for humanitarian reasons as someone mentioned. I believe that in his question, the hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester said that someone might want to move an employee closer to a certain place for health reasons, for example.
These are the same reasons as appear in the amendment. If the circumstances are defined and limited in the law, it could be difficult in future to add other equally legitimate circumstances, even if all parties agree. I believe that it is easier to do that in a policy than in legislation.
For example, in practice, we do not have a very good idea of what such an amendment would do. What does it mean? What does desmonstrated needs of the employee and management mean? How can such needs be demonstrated and to whom does one demonstrate them? Since employees must agree to these transfers, in my opinion, that is the best guarantee that the need is demonstrated.
Personally, I have no quarrel with my colleagues opposite on the objectives being pursued, but I may disagree on the means to reach them, so as not to make the system unnecessarily more cumbersome in an attempt to make it safe from any abuse. I do not want the system to be rigid and prevent the rest of the government apparatus from functioning better.
I believe that both objectives can be reconciled in a more flexible way and that is what we are trying to do in Bill C-26.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to suggest to the minister that we are not trying to be confrontational, we are trying to bring to his attention some of the experiences we are having as members of Parliament when we are dealing on the front lines day to day with people who come to our offices.
Many of the cases or problems we receive in our offices are a result of our constituents not being able to work through or with the various departments or the Public Service itself.
Right now the morale of the Public Service is very low. It is very low for a number of reasons. The relationship between the Public Service and the Government of Canada in the last few years has not been that great.
During a very difficult economic period the resources of the Public Service are called on even more intensely. When our constituents are meeting with public servants whose morale is low, whether it is because they do not have enough man-years or their superiors are not motivating them or treating them properly, it all of a sudden creates a frustration in the way they serve the public. We as members of Parliament are the net beneficiaries of that frustration.
If we are attempting to lift confidence and help those people who are in the most difficulty-that is what the Public Service is there for, to help those who are in most difficulty-then it seems to me that the very asset, the human capital is not showing the kind of goodwill or respect that we could be showing. We must try to motivate its quality of service and its attitude of caring and approachableness because it touches all of the people of Canada in a way that ultimately is a reflection on us.
I do not think it is really an issue of whether one is a Liberal, Conservative or NDP. When people go into a Government of Canada office and they do not feel they are being looked after properly by the bureaucracy or by the public servants, when they come into my office they do not say: "That darned Public Service is PC or Liberal", they hold me as much responsible for poor service by the bureaucracy as they do the Government of Canada.
It is incumbent upon us on this side of the House to suggest that there are things in the government's actions and the way it is restructuring the Public Service that is not lifting the morale of the Public Service. Ultimately this has an effect on the service to the public in every

department and in every region of this country. I cannot imagine a member in this House who does not share this view. It does not matter what department.
In my own community a day does not pass when we do not have people coming to our offices talking about the fact that the department of immigration just does not seem to have the resources to cope with the demands. The department of employment there does not seem to have enough public service support to meet the demand. In the areas related to manpower retraining, public servants with all the goodwill, all the best intentions are pulling out their hair because this government has an attitude.
Did I understand the minister earlier when he mentioned units of labour. Is that the way he quantifies service to the public? A person may come in with a problem and may be there for five or ten minutes. The next person may have a difficulty that takes a public servant an hour or two hours to solve. When we are interacting on problems that are highly personal and we are dealing on a case by case basis, there should not be a clock sitting on the public servant's desk so that he has to think he has to pass so many units through his shop in a particular hour or day.
Our Public Service was the envy of the world for many, many years because of its commitment to caring and quality of service. At one time it was an honour and a privilege to be a member of the Public Service of Canada. When Treasury Board wants to cut the man-years in this section and cut the man-years in another department, it defeats the whole purpose of what our Public Service is supposed to be about because it just takes the heart and soul out of the job.
My message to the government is that it has a very important tool in the public servants of Canada. They are the frontline ambassadors in all the various departments of government. They are the people who on a day to day basis represent the implementation of the legislation that we pass. They can have an effect on the attitudes of people toward the legislation, toward the job we are doing. Right now I think the Government of Canada is not using that instrument to mobilize a positive spirit in this country. I do not think it is respecting the potential for building a new sense of morale in this country. I would urge through you, Mr. Speaker, asking them once
Government Orders
again to go back to their drawing board and try to show a little more spirit of goodwill and appreciation for the quality work they do when they are treated in a fair and equitable way.

Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to say a few words on this legislation.
Yesterday I received a letter from an archivist who works at the National Research Council. I was amazed at what he said to me. I will get to that. One of the comments he made was that the more we change, the more we stay the same. He sent me a copy of a communique which was put out around 1942. The riding of Ottawa Centre used to be called the Ottawa West Liberal Association. I guess there was a Tory and then there was a Liberal.
This particular householder was put out by the Liberal candidate who at the time was attacking the government record. On one side of the householder they have the record of the government of which Dr. Manion was minister of railways and canals from 1930 to 1935. The other side of it had the Mackenzie King government record from 1935 to 1940, and the householder was comparing those records.
In the government record from 1930 to 1935, first they cut the salaries of the public servants by 10 per cent; second, they stopped promotions and increases; third, they dismissed or retired thousands of civil servants without adequate provision for their maintenance; fourth, they removed from office most of the deputy ministers within a short period; fifth, by such drastic measures they disrupted the morale of the service and created an atmosphere of mistrust and apprehension, which destroyed contentment and impaired efficiencies throughout all departments. This was in 1930 to 1935.
On the other hand, from 1935 to 1940, the householder goes on to state that the Mackenzie King government during those five years, one, restored full salaries; two, once again allowed usual promotions and reclassification for all cases; three, introduced the right of appeal for unsuccessful candidates and promotional competitions; four, re-employed large numbers of civil servants let out by the Right Hon. R. B. Bennett and the Hon. Dr. Manion; five, brought back to the service the sense of security lost under the Right Hon. R. B. Bennett and Hon. Dr. Manion and re-established normal morale and efficiencies in government offices.

Government Orders
How true, Mr. Speaker, as my constituent has indicated, that the more we change the more we stay the same.
Basically what was happening between 1930 and 1935 is no different than what has been happening from 1984 to 1992. First, the Public Service has been hit with a salary freeze. We have seen the largest walk-out ever in the history of our Public Service. They walked on Parliament Hill by the thousands. Promotions and increases, as we have seen, to a large extent stopped. There have been massive lay offs. The morale is at an all-time low. As well, in terms of promotions within the Public Service we have not seen many taking place over the past few years.
What needs to be done is for the government to look at all of those issues and try to address one of the most important problems that is now facing our Public Service and that is the issue of morale. The President of the Treasury Board had the chance to visit one of the symposiums at Lansdowne Park. I am sure he would agree with me that if anything he can be very, very proud of the quality of our public servants, the quality of work they do. I am sure he would also agree with me that we have the finest Public Service anywhere in the world.
One thing that was circulating everywhere I went within the Public Service was that there is some element of a morale problem, some element of mistrust, some element of disillusionment, an element of despair. They need leadership at the top which says: "Not only are you doing a good job, but we are going to give you the tools you need in order to continue doing such a good job".
The contracting out, the decentralization which the government has embarked on, the downsizing, as well as a lot of questions when it comes to the partnership between the employee and the employers, all have to be addressed a little more compassionately than the government has done in the past.
To that extent, it is my hope that the government will finally see the light regarding the amendments that my colleague from Ottawa West has put forward before the House of Commons and try to address them in a positive and comprehensive fashion.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak on Motion No. 33 dealing with the amendment to clause 22. I would like to speak to that.
As you know, that concerns the right to deploy. Just to put it in its proper context for people who are watching and listening to us today, I think we should just give a general idea of what this concerns.
When we talk about the right to deploy, we are talking about the right for a department head or anyone who is in a position to do so to send a worker, a public servant, some place else to work in this country. I do not in any way wish to fetter the hands of the government to prevent the government from sending members of the Public Service elsewhere in this country to do their job. I think that is important, that we have to have a work force which is flexible, and the needs change throughout Canada. I think that is a reasonable assumption to make.
However, here it is giving the right to deployment which will affect a worker's entire life, I would say, his surroundings, his environment, when it may be something that may be no more than a whim of the person who has the authority to act.
Whether we are dealing with the Public Service or with any group in this country, I am always concerned when I see power that does not have sufficient constraints, power which can be abused. You have seen I am sure, as I have seen, where things are not specifically excluded, they are included. In fact, it is a rule of law that if something is not excluded, it is included. It can be done if there is not a specific condition that says it cannot be done.
Here, where we are dealing with the deployment of people, of workers, we are dealing with changing their life style, changing their neighbourhoods, changing schools, changing friendships. Many times these types of deployments can be carried out in a way that would have the effect of punishment, perhaps a punishing effect that may be wanted, that may be desired by whomever has this power, or it may be completely unintentional. But it is punishment in any case.

I want to point out that the power the government has under this bill to change a public employee's place of work is quite considerable. This power could be misused. I suggest that this clause we are debating, which deals with that form of abuse of power, does not afford enough protection to the people this legislation applies to. I am
November 19, 1992

referring to the public service employees. Some members opposite will say: "Phillip, there is nothing to worry about. It is no big deal. No way will an individual, a French-speaking employee, be deployed to Saskatchewan for instance, where everybody speaks English, or an English-speaking employee be deployed in Quebec, say in Chibougamau. That is not going to happen." But those things do happen. That is the problem I see with this bill, specifically clause 22, and Motion No. 33 which is designed to improve this provision. There is no protection against that kind of thing happening.
Usually I suggest relying on good old common sense. That is true. Usually we rely on the various directors using common sense so as not to put their subordinates through undue handships. But common sense does not always prevail in government, and I have supporting cases in point. I should pay this government a compliment. I have recently seen a case where good old common sense prevailed. Speaking of the Public Service, you know how the Official Languages Act is being defended, the protection that it is afforded across Canada. The public service employees are in fact at the forefront when it comes to really promoting English and French.
But a little while ago, I have noticed that, using their common sense, some public service employees decided it would serve no useful purpose to translate into French hundreds and hundreds of books like those containing the details on the frigates that were bought and built recently for the Canadian forces. They decided it was not necessary. Unfortunately, it was already done and we paid $100 million for a now useless translation. It is totally useless because when it was finally ready, all the data in these manuals on the frigates were obsolete. Worse still, French-speaking engineers and others who had to use the armed forces books in their work would rather use the English version because they felt more comfortable with the terminology.
After that, the Minister for National Defence appointed several persons-I think there were three from his department, including the much talented Ed Broad-bent-to see if we could use some common sense when applying the Official Languages Act to avoid spending the taxpayers' money on translating everything. Astonishingly enough, a report published two days ago quotes armed forces' personnel as saying that the government could save a lot of money if it stopped translat-
Govemment Orders
ing every thing that moved in the Canadian Armed Forces. We should stick to what is essential.
Just think, Mr. Speaker. Had we done so five years ago, we would have saved $100 million translating technical manuals for the five fregates built in eastern Canada, and that is just one example.
I think common sense is what we need here, and by the way, I want to congratulate the government on its latest report on the use of official languages in the armed forces, because I think that is a good example. Without cutting a single job, without penalizing or punishing anyone, we could have saved $100 million.
That is why when I look at the bill before the House today, I say: Whoa, just a minute. Could we not use our common sense and put some kind of protection in this bill for employees who might be sent elsewhere in Canada on short notice and perhaps even without their consent? Even with their consent, when you work in the Public Service, do you really have a choice when your boss tells you: "Listen Phillip, they need you in Jon-quiere, and you have to move there with your family". I love Jonquiere, and I like Chicoutimi and the Saguenay, but I have made my life in Montreal and my wife works there.
This bill must provide public servants with some protection against this kind of disruption in their lives, which will occur if they can be sent anywhere at all in Canada. If they are willing, there is no problem, but as I said before, do they really have a choice? There is always some pressure involved when people are asked to move, we assume, because of operational considerations.
Since the minister is in the House, I appreciate this opportunity to air this topic, because I know he is aware of my longstanding campaign for bonuses for members of the RCMP, who never received them although they were bilingual. Perhaps we should challenge the use of these bonuses today. I agree this is something that would bear reassessment. However, I think it is really unfortunate that members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police did not get the bonus and received no help at all from the government. The case is now before the courts, so the government could show its goodwill. They already lost once before the Federal Court, which was very clear in its ruling. It said: "Listen, pay those people. You are

Government Orders
wrong and you ought to pay them". Now the case is before the Court of Appeal.
If it goes all the way to the Supreme Court, it will cost-

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I regret the hon. member's time expired about one minute ago. The hon. member for Halifax.

Mr. Speaker, growing up in Canada there are constants that some of us believe and put our faith in. I used to say half in jest and wholly in earnest that the three constants in my family were the Catholic church, the Liberal Party and the Montreal Canadiens. There was probably more truth than fiction in that.
On a serious note, and this bill is a very serious note, one of the things I think Canadians have always believed in and have always taken pride in is that we have and have had the best Public Service of any country in the industrialized world. That is not to say it is perfect. That is not to say things cannot go wrong. That is not to say things do not go wrong.
I think most of us, particularly those of us who were interested in the workings of government and the delivery of services to Canadian citizens through the Public Service, always felt that we could be proud of the Public Service of Canada. One of the reasons that we could be proud of the Public Service of Canada was because a happy work force is a productive work force. A very simple statement.
The problem with Bill C-26 is that it is going a fair way toward destroying that. Too many things have obviously happened already in the breakdown of relations between the workers and the governors. The abandonment of the merit principle which is what effectively is happening under Bill C-26 is possibly the most dangerous development, certainly with regard to the Public Service of Canada, that this government has brought forward.
The Federal Court of Canada in 1992 struck down the Order in Council giving the deputy ministers the freedom to transfer any employee because "it departs substantially from the merit principle". The judge said
regarding one of the government's arguments that if he accepted that particular position: "I would be defeating the whole purpose of the Public Service Employment Act which is to ensure that appointments to the Public Service are made on the basis of merit".
What happens under Bill C-26? It allows managers to move employees to any other position within a level to any other location or any other department without regard to merit or other employees who may be equally or better qualified.
It is interesting that this bill should be up-to-date and that we should be at report stage today. It is interesting we are dealing with these amendments today. Since I became a member of this House four years ago-and I represent Halifax which is the third largest public service town in Canada after Ottawa and Montreal-I have heard a lot of complaints from public servants.
I have particularly heard a lot of complaints from women in the Public Service about a variety of matters. In most cases we were unable to take the matter further because the women out of a fear of reprisal, out of fear of what might happen did not wish to. I would say to them that they would have to allow me to do this if they wanted me to follow the matter up and they would say that no, they were not ready for that. I can understand that. I understand that feeling. It saddens me that that is perceived to be the case in Canada, that it is perceived to be the case in the Public Service of Canada.
As I say, it is particularly interesting that we are discussing the abandonment of the merit principle today because one week ago I met with two young women in my riding of Halifax who have had an exceptionally difficult time over the past year. Their allegations, which will be public before the end of the weekend, were on sexual harassment within the Public Service of Canada. When I asked these young women if they were prepared to go public they said: "Yes, what further can happen to us?"
In doing my job as their representative I have gone further and I have met today with senior officials in the Public Service of Canada. I have to say I was not very happy because there is a mood there, there is a response there in spite of the quite good Treasury Board guide-
November 19, 1992

lines with regard to sexual harassment. I said to one of these senior officials in the department: "Sir, you just do not get it. You just do not understand. There is clearly a gender gap in existence here and you do not see it. We have spoken now for one hour and you still do not understand. There is no point in my walking around this circle any longer".
I use this example because one way or another, the women in the Public Service and the women of Canada are going to ensure that managers, directors and ministers get it. The time when women will sit back and accept this kind of behaviour is over. At the same time, why is the government pandering to this kind of activity by allowing the abandonment of the merit principle? What is going to happen under this regime, under this theory of deployment to women who are being harassed, who are the subject of unfair treatment, whether sexual harassment or another form?
If managers have the right to abandon the merit principle, what recourse are they going to have? Today, in discussing with senior members of the Public Service of Canada the question of what sanctions would be brought forward to a founded charge of sexual harassment I got no response. There was no sanction. No sanction was intended and it was a founded charge.
If today there is no recourse when the merit principle, however tenuously, is still in existence, what in the name of Heaven will happen when the merit principle no longer exists? Where will these people go, whether it is women, minorities, francophones in the famous Trochu or anglophones in Quebec, whether it is Canadians of colour or of a different religious or ethnocultural background? Where will they go if the merit principle has been destroyed?
This is Canada. What are we on about here? What are we doing? How can we stand here in this House and advocate even for one minute this development in what was once a proud Public Service?
In greater Halifax-Dartmouth, there are 30,000 public servants and an awful lot of them are women. An awful lot of them work not in management, not as regional
Government Orders
directors, not as executives within the Public Service but they are ordinary, everyday working people.
Mr. Speaker through you, I am speaking to the minister and beyond the minister, I am speaking to them. I am saying to those public servants in Halifax, in Ottawa and in Montreal, we on this side of the House may have made our mistakes but we believe in the merit principle. We believe that the merit principle is something that you, as the workers in the Public Service of Canada, should be able to hang your hats on.
We deplore a government that would abandon you. We deplore a government so bereft of principle that it throws away this one.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hasten to reassure the hon. member since she makes such a fuss about this that the merit principle is not disappearing. Let her rest assured that the best qualified person will continue to apply on recruitment and promotion. Once somebody has reached a certain level, with their consent they will be moved laterally. That is the flexibility needed in a modem civil service and it will allow women to have wider experience and have access to promotion. I assure the hon. member that she does not need to worry about that. The merit principle is still there for recruitment and promotion.
Apart from that, she seems to consider that managers in the Public Service are all monsters. I assure her that they are competent managers committed to their employees. They come from the civil service. Most of them are from the civil service. Why would they all of a sudden become such monsters? They were raised through the civil service and I do not accept that they are arbitrarily and unfairly lacking in judgment. They are accountable for their actions. I have full confidence that this bill is a great improvement in the modernization of our Public Service.

Mr. Speaker, I am very happy to follow my colleague from Halifax. The kinds of concerns she expressed are exactly the concerns I have heard from women in the Public Service, from people with disabilities in the Public Service and from visible minorities in the Public Service.

November 19, 1992
Government Orders
The minister is absolutely right. The majority of our managers are responsible, well-intentioned people. No, they are not going to turn into raving monsters wielding power irresponsibly overnight because of new legislation that allows them to do it. Legislation is written and restrictions are applied for those whose own moral principles do not guide them in the right direction. There are a few of those in any organization.
The minister, by his own comments, has refused to acknowledge the seriousness of the situation the member for Halifax is bringing to the attention of this House. Harassment is a fact in the Public Service. Discrimination is a fact in the Public Service. There is no other explanation for the fact that 50 per cent of those working for the Public Service of Canada are women and only 15 per cent of those in management are women.
It is not because they are less well educated. The fact is they are better educated. The minister's own department did a major report on women in the Public Service. It demonstrated clearly that attitudes place that glass ceiling above our heads and keep us crashing into it but never going beyond it.
Let me talk about deployments. The minister has said that deployments are not an abandonment of the merit principle. The legislation says otherwise. Deployments move somebody from one job to another. It may be up 10 scales; it may be down 10 scales. The minister has refused to accept amendments that would clarify what a deployment is and what it is limited to.
Normally when people move from one position to another they go through a process of being measured against other people qualified for the position to make sure that the best person gets the job. If there is any violation of that, any violation of fairness, they can appeal the decision and have it corrected.
Numerous situations have been highly publicized in this region and in other parts of Canada where that process has worked to unearth the promotion of favourites as opposed to the best qualified person. Let us not pretend a problem does not exist. If we pretend it does not exist we will never even attempt to solve it.
Motion No. 43 in the package we are dealing with specifically goes to the very misinformation that has been provided to the House that it does not violate the merit principle. It specifically exempts deployments from those sections of the act that protect the merit principle. That
is why I have proposed Motion No. 43. It would at least require that the merit principle apply and that bilingualism and the need to provide services in our two official languages apply to deployments.
The minister's legislation now before the House exempts deployments from any requirements of the merit principle and any requirements to consider the need for bilingual services. I draw the attention of the House to clause 22 which specifically says deployments are exempt from these provisions of the act.
When a manager has total control over whether one progresses in the Public Service, moves sideways for other career opportunities or not, no wonder someone who is already vulnerable in employment the concern is: if I am nice to my boss I will get an appointment and if I am not I will not.
That is reason the Motion No. 40. A deputy could not unduly delay dealing with a complaint and would have to tell the employee in 90 days how the complaint had been dealt with and whether sanctions had been taken, as my colleague from Halifax was saying, to correct a misuse of the deployment system.
It goes back to the fundamental principle that if there is an appeal and a complaint procedure people have a right to timely justice. They have a right to know the information on which the complaint was decided. They have a right, which is not spelled out in the government's legislation, to know that it was dealt with and how it was dealt with.
I have dealt with, as my colleague has, numerous harassment complaints in the Public Service and in the military. They can take months and sometimes years to resolve. This is unacceptable. A deputy cannot sit there with the power over somebody's life and refuse to deal with a very serious complaint which inhibits morale in the Public Service.
In Motion No. 38 I have moved that a section be deleted from this clause. The minister has said deployments are voluntary. Well, that is nonsense. This section of clause 22 says that is Treasury Board has the right to deprive anybody of the right to complain against the deployment they feel is not fair, is not just, is not warranted or is based on favouritism. Why is the minister not prepared to consider that amendment?
November 19, 1992

This group of amendments is intended to try to minimize the damage of this whole section on deployment. It puts power in the hands of managers without requiring any accountability, without requiring any independent review of how they are exercising that power.
The minister stood in the House today and said: "Deployment is not an abandonment of the merit principle". Deployments are just another word for transfers. Transfers have already been tested in the Federal Court of Canada. The right to make transfers without competition has been found to be substantially in opposition to the merit principle. The judge in that case said: "I would be defeating the whole purpose of the Public Service Employment Act which is to ensure that appointments to the Public Service are made on the basis of merit", if he accepted this transfer mechanism of the government.
The minister says things will be used responsibly. In fact we know that the Public Service Commission extended to the external affairs department exclusions from the merit principle even when it knew that power at external affairs was being abused.
Is it any wonder my colleague from Kingston and the Islands has moved several amendments to require the Public Service Commission to act in a fair manner consistent with natural justice when it hears appeals and complaints?
These clauses which we are attempting to amend make the Public Service a chequer-board on which anybody can be moved around at the will or whim of a manager. They completely obliterate the distinction between what is a slight sideward move into another office and what is a major promotion.
If the minister believes that power is not going to be abused, that it is not going to be used to coerce and harass people, the minister is too naive to be sitting in this Chamber. I ask him to look again at those amendments, to see the tremendous damage that will be done to the Public Service of Canada, and to look at some reasonable changes to the legislation before it is too late.

Mr. Speaker, this section on deployment is quite shocking. I simply want to review some of what the government is asking us to accept.
Government Orders
On the right to deploy, except as provided in this act or any other act, the deputy head has the exclusive right and authority to make deployment to or within that part of the Public Service over which the deputy has the jurisdiction. This can be for an indeterminate period. Unless some other period is specified, deployment is for an indeterminate period and on conditions. The main condition is that deployment shall be made in such manner as Treasury Board may direct.
In other words, overriding other considerations Treasury Board can simply direct: do this; do that and deploy them. It is this same Treasury Board that brought us the strike last year, the first strike in the history of the Public Service and one of the most massive strikes in Canada because of the absolute stubbornness of Treasury Board in insisting on the most unacceptable conditions being agreed to before anything else would be negotiated. The record is fully worrisome so far as Treasury Board is concerned.
Then it says that no employee shall be deployed without the consent of the employee. That is a joke. Obviously the alternatives offered will ensure consent and the employee will not have a right seriously to object to what is being done. This will mean that people will be moved without competition, without the right to appeal the move, and their careers will be at the whim of the manager.
In the department of immigration in the Public Service with which I am most familiar this is going to mean in the very near future, in weeks or months, massive redeployment of staff from the offices to be closed all across the country. Perhaps they will be lucky to be redeployed and not just laid off. Of course this depends on how many casuals there are.
But what is planned, so I am advised, is to close all except three offices in Canada. All other Canadians will be given a 1-800 number to phone in to try to get some kind of service from one of those three offices. The employees who had been working in those offices will be redeployed. They will be given the choice of being redeployed or starving, I guess. There will be chaos in the department as a large number of employees in the immigration sector are deployed across Canada or dumped.

November 19, 1992
This act is a very serious weapon of intimidation in the hands of Treasury Board and in the hands of the senior management of the Department of Employment and Immigration.
The public should understand not only how the employees are being mistreated under this act, but how the public is going to be badly served by the government's idea of cost cutting. It clearly is a prelude to privatization of the whole service.

Mr. Speaker, according to journalist Michel Girard of La Presse, flowthrough shares are still the tax shelters that give the biggest tax savings. Investors will tell you that is as it should be since they are the riskiest investment on the market.
It is much less risky to invest in flow-through shares today than it was in the past. Why? Because the mining promoters who have been able to survive the three-year-old depression in the mining industry offer much better mining exploration projects than before. By better, I mean less risky.
Many newcomers invested in poor mining exploration projects in the past and they lost much of their initial investment. In the boom years, 1986, 1987 and 1988, too many junk peddlers pretended to be mining promoters.
Today, fortunately, the junk peddlers have left the mining sector-at least, we hope so.
Nevertheless, many investors have made a bundle by putting some of their savings in flow-through shares.

Mr. Speaker, Ontario com and soybean producers are in an unprecedented cash crisis and need urgent action by the federal government.
The Ontario com crop alone is worth $600 million. Dismal harvesting conditions and high moisture levels mean that 95 per cent of that crop and 40 per cent of the Ontario soybeans are still in the field and unable to be harvested. Much of it will remain there until spring, or at least well after freeze-up.
Because most of the crop is still standing in the field producers will not be eligible for advance payments under the Advance Payments for Crops Act. The lack of an advance payment means many producers are facing a cash crunch.
I call on the government to make the necessary adjustments immediately to allow the unharvested crop to be used under that program.

Mr. Speaker, there are excellent indications that our economy is slowly but surely rising.
Let us consider the following. Retail sales averaged an increase of 1.2 per cent in July and August. Housing starts were up to 6.7 per cent and sales of existing homes rose 4.8 per cent in the third quarter. Labour productivity rose 3.3 per cent in the first half of this year and the Statistics Canada leading indicator continues to increase. We saw the largest increase in 11 months in August of this year.
The government has also turned around an operating budget deficit of $16.1 billion that we inherited, to an operating surplus of over $12 billion in 1991.
The good news is going to keep getting better. We are on the right track. This government is making the proper decisions to ensure a better economic future for all Canadians without borrowing from future generations.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance has indicated that he will be coming forward very shortly with an economic statement in the House, to be delivered within the next week or so, which I think will answer a lot of the concerns the hon. member has raised today.
We too are concerned about employment and the facts that we are experiencing right now. However, I do want to remind the hon. member that between 1984 and 1992,
1,320,000	more Canadians are working than in 1985. Those are a lot of jobs that have been created over the last 10 years. It is not enough to fill the ranks of the
unemployed in this country and we admit that. That is something we all have to concentrate on. However, it is a record that no other country in the world can match per capita and we should be proud of that.

Mr. Speaker, it is obvious that this government fails to understand the real problems of real people.
Last Monday, Jonathan Rosen, aged 31, lined up with 350 other people to apply for one of 20 minimum wage jobs at the Eaton Centre. Six months ago Jonathan Rosen worked for the federal government.
Roberto Soarez, age 28, a university graduate who has been out of work for a year, also lined up for one of those minimum wage jobs. Hie dream is slipping away from my generation. Why does the government refuse to provide innovative and effective programs to create jobs for Canadians and restore the dream?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I said earlier, the purchasing the federal government is doing is creating thousands of jobs in the private sector. They are very important high-tech jobs. We just have to look at some of the contracts that have been announced over the last year. They are very important for our work force right across this country. We are doing something in that regard within the budgetary limits of this government.
I can sympathize with those people who are having a tough time finding a job. It is difficult. As I have said, the unemployment rate is dropping. In the past year 64,000 jobs have been created. Signs of growth in the economy are very promising and we are encouraged that Canada is on the way to recovery.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport.
Earlier today over 2,000 Air Canada employees were outside this Chamber. They are very scared. They and their families are worried about whether or not they will have a job tomorrow, which is no different than the worry that Canadian employees have.
November 19, 1992

I want to ask the Minister of Transport if the government has arrived at a solution, not just for the short term, to keep either carrier or both carriers afloat but for the long term of the Canadian aviation industry? Has the government arrived at a solution?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I mentioned before, a formal proposal was put to us by PWA and its employees this Tuesday. We started working on that proposal immediately after we received it. We have met with representatives of the employees of the company and also of the company that is trying to finalize the transaction. We are working on a very tense schedule to arrive at a solution.
When I came out of a meeting last night, I mentioned that we had made enough progress to believe that we will be able to come to a constructive resolution before the end of this week or early next week. We are taking into consideration, of course, the employment of all the employees of the whole airline system in Canada.

speakerposition: Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister answered only in part.
He indicated that the government was working on the short-term crisis but he did not indicate, like the Minister of Finance did on CBC radio this morning, that the government was recognizing that the marketplace had not worked and that the government was examining options. It called them policy options, although in any other language it is some form of reregulation.
I want to ask the Minister of Transport through you, Mr. Speaker, whether the government finally recognizes that bailouts of a carrier by themselves do not guarantee the survival of the Canadian aviation industry, nor does it guarantee the ongoing operation and ownership by Canadians of the Canadian airline industry.
Is the government prepared to move to ensure that regulation will be put in place to make sure that those carriers can survive in the long term?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is putting words into my mouth or at least he is trying to ignore what I have been saying in this House from the very beginning, in response to questions about this matter.
Oral Questions
I repeat that we must seriously consider this offer to ensure it is not a temporary solution. What we want is a permanent solution to create a system that is as viable, effective, and financially and fiscally sound as it can be.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a number of my constituents have expressed concern that the Canadian middle class may be dying.
In fact, a national newspaper series this week flatly states that that is the case. My question to the Acting Minister of Finance is this. What measures has the government taken, or does it propose to take, to bolster confidence among middle class Canadians to help them be able to plan a secure future?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the first thing we should look at is the United Nations study that picks Canada as the number one country in the world in which people desire to live.
I think that being judged by our peers as being the number one country in itself says that we are doing well and that the middle class by no stretch of the imagination is dying.
There are many things in our economy to encourage the middle class such as low inflation and the low interest rates that we are experiencing now. I am convinced that with the tax cuts that we are having on January 1 which will put $1.2 billion more into the economy, together with all the other factors, the middle class can be asured that they will always have a very strong and important place in Canadian society.

speakerposition: subtopic
Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the President of the Treasury Board.
According to Jacques Pelletier, an analyst with the Central Mortgage and Housing Corporation in Montreal, residential construction preceded the over-all

start-up of economic activity during the last economic recovery.
Unfortunately, the government refuses to recognize the important role this industry has to play in getting the economy started again. speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
