Measures taken in the last budget to allow people to use money in their RRSPs, and the government's general policy, especially as it has affected inflation and interest rates, are the best kind of government intervention, which benefits all economic sectors in this country. We must realize that the best thing the government can do is provide the right conditions for industries to develop, including cheap capital and low mortgages.
My colleague, the Minister of State for Finance and Privatization, has already pointed out the beneficial impact of our policy on inflation and interest rates.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is still directed to the same minister.
The sector worst hit by this recession has been the construction industry, where unemployment is around 50 per cent. There has been a 14 per cent drop in residential construction, as the minister mentioned earlier, in the Montreal area, compared with the previous month alone.
Considering these figures, why won't the government introduce a genuine economic recovery program, such as modernizing infrastructures, in order to give construction and the economy in general a boost? When will we get this program?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a couple of years ago, the government said that the economy was overheating, and that because of very high interest and
inflation rates and artificially high prices for homes, the situation was very precarious. The result is that Canadians are now deep in debt. Governments, companies and Canadians are in debt, and their purchasing power has diminished considerably.
As a government we are trying to do our share to create better conditions and free up capital so that people can borrow, instead of using all the capital available to pay off Canada's debt. We are making an effort to boost recovery in all these sectors, including the residential construction sector.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today the government raised the interest rate by 98 basis points, for a whopping increase of 29 per cent in the past eight days. Last month Canada lost another 28,000 manufacturing jobs and manufacturing bankruptcies are at a record high.
This government has not been able to deal with the deficit, it has not been able to deal with jobs. This government's legacy is the deindustrialization of Canada.
I ask the Acting Prime Minister: Why does this government continue to batter Canada's manufacturers with its high interest rate policy?
High interest rate policy, heavens to Betsy. Jim, you were around when it was 22 per cent.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this country has among the lowest interest rates of any country in the industrialized world. The hon. member should really look around the world and see what interest rates are outside of Canada.
The second point is manufacturing. In fact, unit labour costs are improving in a very important way in manufacturing. We are becoming much more competitive. As a matter of fact as a proportion of our exports, manufacturing has increased from 24 per cent to 26 per cent of our exports. Not only that, but shipments were up 4 per cent in August. The gains were broadly based. Seventeen out of 22 major groups recorded increases.
November 19, 1992

We also have manufacturing capacity utilization numbers. That is very important. They have increased for the second consecutive quarter and 17 of 22 industrial groups recorded capacity utilization gains.
So there are signs of health. There are signs of improvement in the manufacturing sector.

Mr. Speaker, if our interest rates are so low, why are they 4 percentage points higher than the United States and in real terms 6.35 per cent higher than U.S. rates? That is where it counts.
If the minister wants to talk about trade, the trade that really counts is in high-tech goods. Our deficit is $15 billion in high-tech goods and growing.
I go back to the question of our manufacturing sector. Since January 1989 Canada has lost 375,000 jobs, 18 per cent of all its manufacturing jobs.
When will the government admit that its policies are not just working or is its position that we do not need to have a strong manufacturing sector in order to have a strong economic future in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, most Canadians do not know and the hon. member clearly does not know that while the Canadian manufacturing sector represents a smaller share of our GDP than it used to, it has continued to grow in absolute terms. It has continued to grow in absolute terms. Indeed, its size has nearly doubled over the last two decades. To give the impression that there is no manufacturing reality left in Canada is really quite wrong.
I really want to give my hon. friend an interesting answer on interest rates. In the United States, although it is violated sometimes, a state government or governor is not allowed to send an unbalanced budget to the legislature.
In this country provinces can run big deficits, especially the Peterson government and the NDP government in Ontario.
Oral Questions OLDMAN RIVER DAM

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport who answered questions regarding the panel report on the Oldman River dam on the floor of this House on May 2. This is what he said and I quote: "The government responded favourably to 22 of the 23 recommendations contained in the report-.We have accepted that recommendation with the 22 other recommendations contained in this report-.We will ensure that they are implemented".
Could the Minister of Transport tell us why not a single one of those 22 recommendations have been fulfilled now, today, six months later?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I stand by the words I spoke in the House on May 23. Certainly the member will understand that if we want implementation of the recommendations in an orderly fashion, we have to put in place the mechanisms and the process to make sure it will happen so that this thing does not get bottled up.
This is what we are doing at the present time. I stand by what I said in the House of Commons on May 23. We are going to see that these 22 recommendations are implemented but we want to make sure that when it happens we have a process and mechanism in place.

Mr. Speaker, I have a very short supplementary question.
Eighty per cent of the potential environmental damage will occur if the reservoirs are allowed to fill with next spring's run-off. Will the minister get his feet off the recommendations and tell this House in absolute terms that those 22 recommendations will be fully implemented before next spring's run-off goes into the Oldman dam reservoir?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it would be absolutely irresponsible to make such a commitment. We are committed to making sure the recommendations are implemented. Therefore it is absolutely illogical and irresponsible to say that it will be implemented by that date. I will not fall into that trap.

November 19, 1992
Point of Order

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the Board of Internal Economy, I am pleased to answer my colleague, the hon. member for Abitibi.

The press obtained in exchange better meets the needs of the Printing Division of the House in terms of cost benefit, productivity improvements and flexibility for future technology. If my colleague needs more detailed information, I am prepared to ask the officials to provide him with the necessary details.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I have a number of questions for the government House leader about the business of the House. November 19, 1992
the reference to the motion of the committee some time ago when it established a subcommittee.
What I have to know is there unanimous consent? The effect of unanimous consent is that the introduction of the matter will stand but I think we must be absolutely sure what we are agreeing to. I wonder if the hon. member for Kamloops could assist the Chair.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader

It was suggested it should go to the management committee and then after it has a chance to meet, a report would be drafted and submitted to the House of Commons. That is the appropriate procedure and that is what is being done. Tomorrow during Routine Proceedings I expect the report will be tabled and will be adopted on the tabling.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, you referred to unanimous consent. I think the unanimous consent issue before us, if indeed a unanimous consent issue is before us, is whether or not consent was given to interrupting Government Orders yesterday evening in order revert to motions to table a particular committee report. I think that is the focus of the unanimous consent issue.
The position the government takes is that we do not believe there were any improprieties at all. We believe the constitution of the committee on Bill C-91 was perfectly in order. Now that the House management committee has reviewed it and has in fact constituted that committee with the participation and consent of the Whips, that committee is now established.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
We have spent a lot of time on this today and I am going to come back to the difficulty the Chair may be having.

subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
No.
Point of Order

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: The hon. member says no. That is the difficulty I am having.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the difficulty. The management committee was convened today because there was not agreement among the Whips. Therefore the matter had to be referred to the management committee.
It was referred to the management committee and therefore the committee rendered a decision. That decision will now be represented in a committee report which will be tabled at the appropriate time. That is the procedure we follow.
As a matter of fact, Mr. Speaker, that was the procedure that we reconfirmed in the committee session earlier today. In other words, if the Whips cannot come to an agreement it must go to the management committee for a decision. That is what we did. The Whips could not come to an agreement and it was then placed before the management committee. It was on the agenda, it was dealt with.
That committee presumably will submit a report during Routine Proceedings tomorrow and then that report will be deemed to have been adopted. That is the procedure that we accepted in the committee today and I suggest, Mr. Speaker, that that is the process we should follow now.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my recollection of the events is that names were submitted yesterday, or prior to yesterday, by the Whips of all three parties to participate in the legislative committee for Bill C-91.
There was some challenge subsequent to that report being received by the House as to whether the report was properly constituted. There were some discussions this morning in the House management committee about how to establish greater certainty that the Whips had, in fact, put names in for legislative committees, in a generic sense.
There was also some discussion and disagreement about precisely what happens after the Whips submit names for legislative committees. There was never any dispute that the Whips of the three parties had submitted names for this legislative committee. The names are as they were tabled yesterday in the House by me on

November 19, 1992
Point of Order
behalf of the chairman of the House management committee.
I take the position, Sir, that that committee report has been received and that any dispute surrounding its reception has now been cleared up.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I just want to clarify one thing. The parliamentary secretary for the government House leader said that yesterday the report was properly constituted. We had a long debate about it here in the House. We decided in the House management committee that the report was not properly constituted because there was no meeting.
As a matter of fact, Mr. Speaker, the House management committee had to pass a resolution to adopt the report about a quarter to twelve. Therefore, I want to make it clear that yesterday's report was not properly constituted because there was no quorum, the meeting did not take place, and there was no unanimous consent.
I want to make the record clear, that consent was given through a House management committee vote in the committee room at a quarter to twelve today and not yesterday.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what my friend, certainly inadvertently, left out of the true statement that he just made is the fact that the House management committee has been operating for over a year now, I believe, under a system whereby if the Whips submit names for a committee that that authority is then delegated to the Whips to present that report through the clerk without a formal meeting of the House management committee taking place.
The discussion that took place in the House management committee today was how to achieve greater certainty that the Whips had in fact submitted the names. It was agreed that certainty could be achieved through requiring the signatures of the Whips to be attached, and that is the process that has been agreed will be followed in future cases.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: The difficulty that the Chair is having is this: The first thing I have to be sure of is, do the Whips agree as to the content of the report? If there is agreement, and remember it has already been presented to the House and was accepted unanimously-

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext: Which report?

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
A subcommittee. If there was unanimous consent, I am having very great difficulty in understanding why procedurally we need another submission of the report to the House.
It seems to me if there is now unanimous consent, the matter is over with and it stands. If I could find some rationale for coming to any other conclusion, I might be able to follow it but I am having difficulty.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
Perhaps I can be helpful by suggesting the report tabled yesterday was an illegitimate report.
It was a report of a meeting that never occurred. How can you table a report of a committee that never took place? That was the argument we made.
I gave notice last night that we would raise it today. We said for the Chair to accept a report of a committee that never occurred seemed to be ludicrous, quite frankly. It seemed to be unreasonable.
In your judgment, Mr. Speaker, you suggested we attempt to resolve this in the management committee, and we did.
My friend, the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader said, as an item of business, the Whips have not been able to come to an agreement on the composition of the committee to receive witnesses to consider Bill C-91.
The question was then put to the committee. The motion was: "I recommend the following composition". There was some comment and I participated in it. Then there was a vote and it passed. In other words, the committee dealt with this very specific issue as it should have.
I therefore submit that since the committee has now held a meeting and dealt with the impasse successfully, it is now able to draft a report and submit it to the House. Upon submission, it will be considered adopted.
The appropriate time to do that is during Routine Proceedings, and we would expect to see it then.
Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of
the Government in the House of Commons): Mr. Speaker, I just want to make the obvious point.

For well over a year the procedure on legislative committees has been that each of the Whips submits the names of his representatives. That is deemed to constitute a meeting of the committee for the purposes of establishing a committee. That has been used for over a year with no difficulties.
On that basis, my parliamentary secretary tabled the report yesterday. The House leader of the New Democratic Party stood up and said: "Whoops, tilt". His Whip had not put in the right name. We subsequently found out his Whip had put in the name.
The names of the members on the committee are now known and there is no question as to who the people are. Yesterday the House unanimously agreed to the establishment of the committee with the same names that were known yesterday.
Do we now have to wait until tomorrow? I know one should not ascribe motives, but the net effect of this alteration of one year and one-half or more procedures has been to delay the start-up of this committee.
The purpose the New Democratic Party had in mind by misinforming the House as to what its Whip had done or not done is apparently part of the games around here. The public should know the reality is the committee is established by unanimous consent. The membership is known. Perhaps it is necessary to keep delaying for the purpose of delaying, but I wonder if the people of Canada think they are getting good value from their parliamentarians who are using these tactics.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
I have been trying to find a way to resolve this difficulty without having to make hard rulings.
I cannot make any further decisions until I know if there is consent to the substance of the report as a consequence of the discussion that took place this morning. There has been no agreement on the first report, as my colleague, the House leader for the New Democratic Party has said and as my Whip from Saint-Leonard has indicated. That is the reason why it went back to the management committee for further deliberations.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
I may be losing track of this, but I thought there were two situations yesterday when the hon. parliamentary House leader proposed the report to the House and there was objection taken to the first. It seems to me that is the question I now have to answer, if I have correctly understood everybody.

Business of the House
I will give that some consideration and report back to the House. I do not think I need any further argument. If there is something I have missed, I will need further argument, but I do not think I have.

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader

speechtext:
There is one additional piece of information that might be helpful. The Chair accepted the report tabled yesterday of a meeting that did not occur. It provides additional power now to the parliamentary secretary if this is accepted.
It provides additional power to the chair of the management committee, if that person is allowed to table reports of committee meetings that never occurred. I think that is a very dangerous precedent.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subsubtopic: REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE ON HOUSE MANAGEMENT
speechtext:
In this place and in our committees, much of the lubricant to make things flow comes from goodwill, good faith, character and integrity.
Often we can agree with each other's suggestions, respond to each other and communicate with each other without a formal meeting actually taking place. I think my friend from Kamloops would acknowledge there have been a number of instances in the past year and beyond when committees have been constituted by consultation among the Whips, without a meeting ever actually taking place and through the delegated authority from the House management committee being deposited with the clerk.

Madam Speaker, I want to express my thanks for the consideration of the hon. Speaker who was in the Chair an hour and a half ago in reminding me that I have these five minutes.
Before Question Period I described what I think is wrong about the government's proposed policy of deployment of public servants. I will not repeat that now. I want to use these few minutes to suggest what I think is a better way.
I am referring to Motion No. 33 standing in the name of the hon. member for Kamloops. I will read the motion because this concerns a great deal of the public:
Motion No. 33
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 22 by adding immediately
after line 14 at page 12 the following:
"(2) In applying subsection (1) Treasury Board shall, in the deployment of an employee, include in its direction the following factors:
(a)	the need to develop the employee through additional work
experience;
(b)	the demonstrated need to fill a vacancy on an immediate
basis;
(c)	the demonstrated needs of both the employee and management and;
(d)	compassionate grounds."
I think that this is a very reasonable and preferable alternative to what the government has proposed that I criticized before.
In my 18 years as a labourer on a factory floor in a unionized plant we had many disputes. I was involved in some of them as an employee; I was involved in some of them as an officer of the union. Generally speaking, we resolved those disputes not to perfect satisfaction but to workable relations. I might add, and I do not take all the credit for this, during the time I was working there and during the time I was an officer, there was no work stoppage. There was no strike. I credit in part the management of that enterprise which was a local branch of a large multinational corporation. I credit it in recognizing the necessity of considering the employees' needs when it expects the employee to consider the necessity of the employer's needs.
These are four very simple matters to recognize, not easy, but clear enough. One is the need to develop the employee through additional work experience, so if there is an improved job to be done, a better job through more experience, the employee, all employees, should have the same chance through the provisions for competition, through the provisions for appeal which appear to be denied by the government's new proposal.
Second, there should be a demonstrated need to fill the vacancy on an immediate basis. We had occasions when somebody had to fill in on a temporary basis because of an absence or an extra workload, but that did not create a permanent position. That should be observed here in the much greater matter of deployment, that maybe arrangements need to be made temporarily but it is different from using them as the grounds to do it permanently.
Third, the demonstrated needs of both the employee and management should be observed. This is not reflected in the company's proposal. It does say that no employee shall be deployed without the consent of the employee, but it does not give the employee any ground to stand on. If he or she feels that the deployment would be disadvantageous, he or she is not given by the government's proposal any ground to stand on to make that point, any ground by which to justify refusal.
November 19, 1992

Finally, on compassionate grounds, the employee is expected from time to time to recognize the employer's unusual need. I ask that the same be written in, that the employee may have an unusual need to reject the deployment.
Those are grounds for approving this very good amendment proposed by the hon. member for Kamloops.

When there is no need for a position in one location and that person could be utilized in another, it is extremely advantageous to both the employee and the employer to move the best person with his or her consent. This gives both sides flexibility, which is something we need in the government and the Public Service to become more efficient and respond to the needs of the public.

Motion No. 45
That Bill C-26 be amended in Clause 23 by adding immediately
after line 19 at page 14 the following:
"(2) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), the
Commission shall, in respect of an appeal under subsection 21(1),
make regulations
(a)	requiring the disclosure of any document or information of which the appellant has no knowledge or that has not been communicated to the appellant and on which the deputy head might rely;
(b)	prescribing a notice period of not less than two weeks in respect of the time and place of any hearing held for purposes of the appeal."
Government Orders
She said: Madam Speaker, the intent of this motion has been more fully dealt with by a couple of amendments proposed by my colleague, the member for Kingston and the Islands.
As he mentioned in discussing those amendments, we are endeavouring to correct the situation that is nearly a decade old, whereby a joint committee of both chambers of this Parliament and of all parties has repeatedly recommended the Public Service Commission have regulations as to how it conducts its hearings.
It has failed in the past to conduct its hearings with due regard for fair process and natural justice.
The amendment I have moved would require the Public Service Commission to make regulations. For nearly a decade it has persistently resisted the expressed views of reports to this Parliament from its own committees.
It has delayed responding to those reports. It has come close to expressing contempt for the opinions of parliamentarians as put forward in the reports of that committee to this Chamber and to the other place.
The commission is now saying it is going to conduct an inquiry to see what kind of regulations it should have.
After nine years of resisting the views of this Parliament as to fair process for employees appealing a decision, I think it is time for this Parliament to tell the commission it must have regulations and this is its opportunity to do so.
It is really quite simple but there is nothing in place, believe it or not, that now requires somebody who brings an appeal to the Public Service Commission to have access to all the information that will be used in considering that appeal.
It is impossible for an appellant to have fair justice, if he or she has objected to a decision and walks into a hearing not even knowing what information will be used in that hearing. Yet that is what happens consistently and that is why the joint parliamentary committee on the scrutiny of regulations has twice recommended regulations to ensure information is available to people whose livelihoods depend on the decisions made by the commission.
The other thing that can and does happen is people are not given adequate notice of a hearing that affects the very continuance of their employment in some cases. It affects whether they are dealt with fairly in promotions. The second part of this amendment requires the commission to have regulations saying people must have

November 19, 1992
Government Orders
at least two weeks' notice of the time and place when their own appeal will be heard.
It is only fair to allow a person to consider the information to be used in the hearing and consult counsel or a union representative. Yet there is no requirement and no body I am aware of that operates without regulations with respect to notice and the information to be provided to the person whose very future depends on the decision of that tribunal.
That is the sole purpose of this amendment. I ask, as my colleague from Kingston and the Islands did, that the government consider why it is willing to let the commission continue to stonewall the expressed wish of Parliament.

Madam Speaker, I want to speak to this particular motion and add a few comments.
I want to support the motion and the basic principle that we need to ensure the Public Service Commission will implement regulations to ensure due process and appeals. Surely that is a basic, fundamental principle upon which our labour relations are based.
My party, the Liberal Party of Canada, stands for a professional civil service that is non-partisan in nature and treats all employees with respect and fairness. It should be a model of labour relations in Canada. It should be a model in terms of the treatment of its employees as well.
The Public Service should be responsive to the needs of Canadians, draw the finest and the best and be able to keep them as well. We unequivocally support the merit principle. My colleagues and I denounce patronage and favouritism in the civil service.
We also believe deployments and re-deployments without consideration of the merit principle flaunt that principle. They counteract it and are inappropriate.
I note here that casual employees have virtually no rights, and I find that most unfortunate and inappropriate I might add. I think the whole concept of hiring any qualified person available is not necessarily a fair one. It could disregard the merit principle and we have to be on guard for that kind of possible violation.
I have noted on a number of occasions in this House that contracting out can cost more. While there have
been deep cuts to the civil service and at times, the government has bragged about those, it has been unable and/or unwilling to show how many dollars have been spent on contracting out, and whether or not that contracting out has been more expensive for Canadians if one looks at the over-all total.
That is a question I placed on the Order Paper to which I failed to receive an appropriate, adequate or precise answer.
I note the bill does not deal with pension reform, and that is unfortunate. It was a golden opportunity to do so, and it could have addressed the whole notion of de-indexing pensions, which people are very nervous about and my party opposes.
I believe, as a former senior civil servant, there is an excessive use of regulations in some certain instances. There are too many exclusions from the collective bargaining process, and the increased flexibility for managers is not counterbalanced by increased accountability.
To sum up, I would say that the main thrust of this bill, and a veiy sound one at that, is to try and come up with a policy, a somewhat different one if you want, ensuring that our Public Service will be able to meet today's and tomorrow's needs, to retain the best men and women to answer the call of the Canadian people and provide them with top quality services.
My fear is that, if we get overly concerned with flexibility-as desirable as it may be at times-we will unwillingly end up missing out on the merits we were looking for, that is, the principles we wanted to be applied, and that would be unfortunate.
I noted in several instances, as you probably did as well, Madam Speaker, that many organizations besides the unions and the employees involved are concerned about these changes. Why? Certainly there are broadminded people in these organizations, men and women who understand what the Public Service is about and share the principles I just mentioned, men and women who want to make sure that our Public Service is the best there is. If these people are concerned-and several are both against and concerned-why go ahead at this time?

Why not stop and reconsider, and try to come up with sound proposals that would address their worst fears.

I think it is important to ensure that our civil service remains at all times at the service of Canadians, staffed with the very best possible and, I stress again, with a code of conduct and labour relations that are the model for the country. If we, as the highest court of the land, are unable to give the example to other employers then why should we expect other employers to do what is right for their employees.

That is why I rose in this House today to share with you my thoughts about what should be done.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I want to make a few comments with regard to Motion No. 45. As my colleague from St. Boniface has indicated, I too am very much in favour of having a professional Public Service. By and large I think we do, but some of the rules and regulations which they, as employees, have to engage in from time to time leaves one wanting to ask a number of questions. Motion No. 45 addresses a very important aspect of the appeal process that an employee of the Public Service of Canada would have at his or her disposal should that be necessary.
The whole question on the issue of due process is something which has been a major study, if you will, in administrative law on a variety of different subjects. I would think that the parliamentary secretary, who is in the Chamber today, would want to concur that the rules of natural justice ought to apply to individuals who may be seeking an appeal based upon a particular complaint and/or an unfair action which may have been taken against them.
I want to indicate to the House regarding disclosure, the motion in part reads:
(a) requiring the disclosure of any document or information of
which the appellant has no knowledge
You do not have to be a Philadelphia lawyer to figure out that when you go before a commission which is going to
Government Orders
make a decision which affects you personally and how you will interface with other employees, and may have dire consequences as to whether or not your position will remain in effect, it is essential in 1992 and certainly for years to come that germane information be made readily available to the person in question.
Canadians would find it rather repugnant if many of them were aware that under this particular procedure, documents would not necessarily be included and verbal information, files of that nature, were not fully disclosed to the appellant in question.
That is wrong. It is terribly wrong. People might want to argue that this is not a court of law. I suggest through the Chair to members opposite that we are talking about a quasi body which has particular functions. In this day and age when employment opportunities are so scarce as a result of government policy which I know Madam Speaker does not agree with, it is even all the more important to make sure that our regulations pursuant to appeals certainly follow a due process in the rules of natural justice.
We are not asking for the moon. We are asking for such basic things as requiring the disclosure of any document or information of which the appellant has no knowledge or, in another incident, that has not been communicated to the appellant and on which the deputy head might rely.
It would be terribly, terribly unfair. If you are going to a civil proceeding or a civil trial and information is sprung at one side, whether it be the appellant in a particular case, if that information is not made readily available it makes it very difficult if not next to impossible to prepare a proper case in order to respond to some of the allegations and to some of the suggestions which may be forthcoming.
The second part of it is very very simple. It is obvious. Perhaps it needs to be underlined. The second part of Motion No. 45 reads:
(b) prescribing a notice period of not less than two weeks in
respect of the time and place of any hearing held for the purposes of
the appeal.
Two weeks is basically 10 working days, if that is what we determine under the purposes of the regulations. Surely an individual who has been aggrieved and wishes

November 19, 1992
Government Orders
to appeal that decision can have 10 working days or the equivalent of two weeks in order to prepare that appeal.
Those of us who have never been in situations or have had to go before a board which may adjudicate on our futures or how we interface with others workers in the work place might not find this to be overly important. I suggest to the Chair that when an appellant, an individual who has been aggrieved, has lost that and wishes to appeal that to a higher body, that individual may want to take, not an unreasonable period of time, but some time to reflect upon the decision in order to prepare a case which is reasonable, which is understandable and which they are comfortable with in presenting on appeal.
Therefore, it would seem to me that two weeks is not an inordinate amount of time to give to an individual who is aggrieved, has not been successful with that particular grievance and is now appealing that particular decision.
I want to share with the Chair that I would hope the rules of natural justice give the right to a hearing. It also implies that a fair hearing is a right. It would be similar if you, Madam Speaker, were to hear a point of order which was complicated in its nature and said to the House when 15 or 25 members wish to stand to make an intervention: "Well, I am not going to listen to anyone. I am going to make my decision". I think the regulations in part under this particular Motion No. 45 give the individual and the system a greater assurance that things will not be done in an arbitrary way. Notice and information will be provided so that proper and fair decisions can be made. After all, governments at the national level as well as at the provincial and municipal levels have to provide an example for the private sector and for the non-profit organizations throughout this country.
We are not asking for something which is totally unreasonable, out of line or unfair. I think it meets the test of being very reasonable and appropriate and also meets the test of rules of natural justice. I hope that members across the way will give careful consideration to the contents of Motion No. 45, keeping in mind that all of us from all political parties are interested in making certain that the professionalism of the Public Service is of a standard that cannot be questioned at any time.

Madam Speaker, I am going to be very brief on this particular amendment. It is important to say that this amendment is attempting to ensure, as previous speakers have said, that natural justice is done. Everywhere else in Canada we believe in the basic principle of natural justice. To put this into plain language, what this amendment calls for is that the employee must be told what the employer is going to use against him or her and you be told in
November 19, 1992

sufficient time, two weeks, in order to prepare a response. It is as simple as that.
Both opposition parties would not feel so strongly in favour of this particular amendment and probably would have been satisfied with the government's clause on this had we not had a situation where three times out of the last nine years, in fact since the Liberals were in government, the agency responsible for the implementation of this act has been advised in reports that natural justice was not being served and they were failing very seriously in this regard. Three times in nine years they were failing and refused to protect in the most basic way the right of workers to a fair and open hearing.
I believe that clarifies why people on this side of the House are not satisfied to hear the government say: "We will protect the workers". She said: Madam Speaker, I want to speak very briefly on this and again on the issue of fair and equal treatment.
What this clause that I am proposing to amend does is define who an employee is for purposes of bargaining rights and any collective rights under the Public Service Employment Act.

One of the things it does is exclude part-time employees. Part-time employees and their access to full rights as workers is an important issue for women. It is an important issue for people with disabilities. Increasingly it is an important issue for all workers who are concerned about blending their work environment with their personal responsibilities. I think the government is well aware that in the private sector, as in the public sector, that is becoming a key issue on how one attracts and retains qualified productive employees. To exclude parttime employees from any collective rights whatsoever is archaic, to say the least. The government has taken one progressive step in giving part-time employees access to pension rights. It is also time to give them access to other rights as employees.
Motion No. 53 is a similar motion. In the legislation that is before us, "casual employees" are excluded from any rights. We previously debated casuals in the federal government. This legislation sets up a whole new group of employees that can be hired or fired on a moment's notice or on a whim. They have no rights. Nonetheless the legislation is set up so that they can continually, year after year, be working as casuals for the Government of Canada.
It is wrong to have casuals who may be with you year after year with absolutely no rights as employees. These would be full-time people who would have no benefits, no rights to grieve, no rights to complain if they have been dismissed, no matter how long they have been with the government. They have no right to appeal any action taken against them.
This leaves us open again to full arbitrary action by those who have control over their lives. In both these cases, a humane, fair and just work place requires that these employees have access to rights.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, once again I would like to say thank you to my colleague from Ottawa West. I do recognize some of her concerns.
Today, part-time employees who work more than 12.5 hours per week have collective rights. They have had them since 1967. That is not going to change under the bill.
Government Orders
We did make some extensions with regard to 3,000 and
4,000	employees who were previously excluded on confidential grounds unrelated to labour relation confidentialities. We have made some rights in that area.
We are speaking of casual labour. I know and understand the concerns that the people have, but the amendments with regard to casual labour in clause 16 of the bill provides that casual employees may be appointed for a period of up to 90 days. That can be extended, but in no case can they work more than 125 days.
This is consistent with many of the labour relations acts right across the country. We are being extremely consistent and we have recognized the concerns of our people.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member for the government side of the House is absolutely right. The government is consistent. It is consistently mean-spirited and determined to take away every right that a public sector worker under its jurisdiction has, wants or should have under what we, as Canadians, believe are basic rights of working people.
It is quite misleading for the hon. member to say that part-time workers have had the right after so many hours for an indefinite period of time. Yes, that is true, but casual workers do not. There are casual workers right here in this building who have been working for the government for 20 years and are still casual workers.
They have no rights to vacation, they have no rights to collective bargaining protection, they have no rights to union protection and they have no rights to grieve. They have no rights, period. They have worked here for 20 years, and I can parade them out for this government any time it wants to know who they are.
The problem is that they are afraid to speak out. They are afraid to say anything because they have no rights. I am sorry if I sound a little bit uptight about this but it is a very important issue. It is time that workers who work for this government and this country get the protection that all workers should enjoy. They should not be treated as a different class of worker for endless years.
We are not talking about casual workers when it is 20 years. There is nothing casual about that. That is a lifetime commitment to this country and to this government.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is really important that we start to see the pattern emerging here. We are starting to see a pattern of amendments to the Public Service Staff Relations Act that include things like endless terms for casuals, with no willingness to take a look at the unfairness of that, and clauses such as those we have just had motions on that take away workers' rights and allow the government to transfer people with impunity. All the way through the discussions on this in the community hearings, in the committee meetings following that, in the clause by clause debate in committee, and now in the House we consistently see that paternalistic big brother attitude of trust us, trust the Public Service Commission. It said it would do it years ago and it still is not doing it.
It is important that we start to view this document for what it is, and that is a mean-spirited, nasty document that is designed to take away rights. It is designed to set the pace because what happens in the federal government service sets the attitude and the pace for federal

November 19, 1992

jurisdiction collective bargaining and federal jurisdiction corporate attitudes.
It is important too when we address the amendment regarding grievances to be very clear on what this motion is about. It would bring the rights of public sector workers into line with the rights of private sector workers. It is not a lot to ask, not an unreasonable request. That is in the area with regard to grievances.
As it currently stands, the Public Service Staff Relations Act without this amendment does not allow unions to have policy grievances. This motion would remedy that omission in the act. If the representatives of the worker are truly to be regarded as partners in the work place, as we have heard so vociferously from the government in the past couple of years about the partnership in the work place, the unions then must have the right to pursue work place issues which affect their membership and even in the absence of an individual griever.
Why would the union have to have the right to pursue a grievance in the absence of an individual griever, one might ask. Because in many instances a worker is too intimidated because of threat or fear, it may be unfounded fear, of reprisals if he or she grieves against the employer.
This amendment allows the union, on behalf of that worker who is afraid to grieve, the right to grieve on his or her behalf. That is all this amendment does. The government has decided in its wisdom this is another right that we are not prepared to allow our workers to have.
This is not a new concept in the labour relations field. It is something that private sector workers enjoy under labour codes across this country, including the Canada Labour Code. If you work for the government, you do not have the rights that a worker in the private sector under the Canada Labour Code has.
Given the restrictions on collective bargaining already faced by the unions in the federal public sector, this motion is a very small step toward the recognition that the workers and their representatives have the right to seek and receive a determination of their rights. It is about protecting an individual worker and ensuring that
Government Orders
every opportunity is there so that an aggrieved worker with no fear of repercussion can grieve.
It is not a frivolous motion. It is not intended to open the door to a flood of silly grievances or bum beefs. It is a serious amendment that would ensure a worker has the right without fear of recrimination to grieve that he or she is protected. It is also a motion that would provide the union with the right to a policy grievance if the worker did not like the working conditions but it was contrary to what has been agreed to in the collective agreement.
I would ask again that the government take this particular motion into account as being a fair-minded one and when we vote on these motions on Monday would support this amendment.

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to repeat what has already been said by my colleague from Mission-Coquitlam. However, it is time for the Public Service Employment Act to come a little closer, for its own employees, to rights enjoyed by every other worker across this country. The issue of the individuals who are afraid of reprisals if they stand up for their rights is a very real one. It is becoming even more crucial because of the amendments in this piece of legislation before us.
We have talked earlier about casual employees who will have no rights. A whole new classification of employees is being created in Bill C-26. We have talked about deployment, which is going to apply, ultimately, to virtually any appointment within the Public Service except the initial hiring. There will be virtually no right to appeal or complain against deployments which can move one from here to Halifax, from Halifax to Vancouver, from one department to the other, up the scale or down the scale of salaries. Because of those deployments, opportunities to advance and fear of being demoted will depend on the goodwill of the supervisor, there is going to be even more reluctance than there is now to complain in an informal way or launch a formal grievance.
It becomes even more important then that public service employees have the ability to complain or launch

Government Orders
a grievance on behalf of a group of employees who are all affected, rather than each of them having to individually launch a grievance and be subject to reprisals.
One may say that does not happen. We have wonderful managers and that simply does not happen. The whole grievance procedure ensures it happens. The whole hierarchy in the Public Service ensures it happens. I have seen complaints from people about harassment that drag on month after month after month, going up the line from a supervisor who is responsible to a supervisor above him or her. Each one simply reaffirms the decision taken at the previous level. That is the way it works, let us be honest.
People stop making complaints, accept unjust treatment and are subject to reprisals when they do complain or grieve. If any of us are listening to our constituents who are Public Service employees, we know it happens. That is why this ability to take a collective agreement is essential if we truly want a public service where harassment and reprisals against people for standing up for their rights are not the rule but the exception. Then these amendments to the grievance procedure are absolutely essential.

speechtext:
that Bill C-330, an act to amend the Criminal Code and the Parole Act, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, on behalf of my constituents in Hamilton, the victims of crimes and their families, the
55,000	Canadians who have signed the petition in support of Bill C-330, and on behalf of the regional municipality of Waterloo, the corporation of the city of Cambridge, the corporation of the city of Kitchener, the corporation of the city of Hamilton, the Canadian Police Association, the Ontario Police Association, and the Ontario Police Chiefs, it is an honour and a privilege to rise in this House to debate second reading of Bill C-330.
As many of us watch and participate in the House today and as many of the Canadians who have written to me are watching and are aware of this debate, the bill rose out of concerns of victims of violence. It arises from the multitude of tragedies and unspeakable anguish of victims of violent crimes, be they the victims of an assault or the parents or spouse of a deceased victim who have lost faith in our system of justice and want change.
Let me be clear at this point on their aspirations. These victims of violent crimes do not want to get even. They are not looking for any kind of revenge. They want a system of justice to take into consideration; first, the views of the victim of a violent offence as it relates to the sentencing of the individual charged with an offence, and second, the protection of the public from violent offenders.
It is truly amazing from the many, many town hall meetings I attended with members of families who are themselves victims of violence that these families are not out for money. They are not out for revenge. They just plain and simple do not want to be victimized again. They do not want others to go through the same tragic circumstances they have had to live through.

November 19, 1992

Victims of violent crimes and hundreds of thousands of Canadians know that despite the changes made to date on parole legislation through Bill C-36 and the codification of existing legal practices and conventions through Bill C-90, this is just the first step. So much more can be done to address the concerns of victims of violence.
Back in March 1991 I met with members of the Edwards family in my Hamilton constituency office. The Edwards family are the victims of a most brutal crime. Sitting across from me was Michelle Edwards who watched as her parents were murdered in their home. With her was her brother-in-law, Terry Smith, who has been a valuable friend and confidant and someone who has helped me construct this bill from that very first visit back in March 1991.
They were in my office just a week after Michelle's parents were murdered. Their fear at that point, a week after that murder, was that there was a good possibility they had heard that the murderer of Michelle's parents, if convicted of the crime, would be released from prison in as little as 15 years. In fact, their fear was that if convicted the individual would be eligible for escorted day passes. There were questions as to how the murderer was out on bail. He was charged with a violent offence at the time and was out on bail. The very woman sitting across from me in my Hamilton constituency office had watched this individual murder her parents while out on bail.
Upon completion of the six week trial the individual in question was convicted of two counts of first degree murder and one count of attempted murder. As it was described to me the Edwards family truly believed that the individual would serve the rest of his life in prison for these crimes.
In fact, when they came out of the court room after having sat through all that trial and having watched the individual be convicted of his crimes, people were coming up to them and saying: "Congratulations. You will not have to worry about him anymore; he is in jail for the rest of his life with no chance of parole". To their horror and in fact disgust they painfully learned that not only would this individual serve just one sentence for all three convictions, or as Michelle put it to me: "He killed my mother. The death of my father and the attempted murder of me were freebies". He would be eligible for full parole in just 15 years. In fact, under the current law he is eligible for an escorted temporaiy absence today.
If that crime had happened to any of us sitting in the
Private Members' Business
House today, how do you think we would respond? From the beginning Bill C-330 was a response not only to this personal and tragic case but it also became a focus of bitterness and sorrow following the murders of Nina de Villiers, Kristen French, Leslie Mahaffey and Kayla Klaudusz. All these shook southern Ontario specifically in 1991.
Before explaining the details of Bill C-330 to this House I want to explain the government's legislative initiatives for the public. This is all necessary in order to highlight the fact that even the most recent amendments to our laws fall very short of the types of amendments victims of crime and the cause of public protection deserve.
Bill C-36 introduced by the Solicitor General in October 1991 and proclaimed in June of this year is in essence a reshuffling of the deck of parole and the related provisions of the Criminal Code. What I mean by this is that the bill was heralded by the Solicitor General in the following way: "The act contains significant measures to reform the legislation. Above all, these measures assert that the primary duty of the corrections system is protection of the public". In fact, Bill C-36 did attempt to comfort the victims of violence but what it did not do was assure those victims of violence. What it did do is create more laws but not enough justice.
How about those dangerous offenders, offenders who are convicted and sentenced to federal prisons for offences such as sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, assault with a weapon and murder? Violent offences. The changes to legislation with respect to these offenders were not the types of changes that would benefit public protection.
For offences other than murder, offenders are eligible for full parole after serving one-third of their sentence. If the National Parole Board considers an offender fit for parole they can be paroled. However, under a provision of Bill C-36 called statutory release at two-thirds of their sentence, offenders must be released from prison.
I ask you, Mr. Speaker, if certain offenders have not been released at the one-third point of their sentences because the National Parole Board considers them unfit for full parole does this legislation meet the test of public protection if they must be allowed full parole after serving just two-thirds of their sentence? No.

Private Members' Business
The government's bill fails the test of public protection. It is nothing short of a farce. It has been allowed to trumpet this bill as representing the paramountcy of public protection. Nothing could be further from the truth.
At the time of passage of Bill C-36 we in the official opposition called on the government to simultaneously provide sentencing legislation because we cannot have one without the other. Finally it produced Bill C-90 which we on this side of the House believe also fails the test of public protection.
What does this House know about our system of justice and parole? The House recalls the case of Daniel Gingras, an inmate at the Edmonton institution who escaped while on escorted temporary absence to the West Edmonton Mall. It was deemed to be for rehabilitative reasons. He was allowed to go to the mall because it was his birthday.
Daniel Gingras was able to convince the warden of the penitentiary to allow him to go with an escort smaller than the larger burly escort who was scheduled to take him. He escaped his guardian's custody and while at large from prison murdered two people and later was convicted on two counts of first degree murder.
There are so many other examples, all violent criminals, all individuals who are convicted of murder or rape. Daniel Gingras as we mentioned on escorted temporary absence in the province of Alberta, went on to murder two more people. Alan Legere on medical temporary absence in New Brunswick went on to murder four people. Patrick Mailloux on day parole in New Brunswick went on to murder one more person. Joseph Fredricks under mandatory supervision in Ontario went on to murder one person. Melvin Stanton on day parole in Ontario went on to murder one person. David Rose, out on day parole in Alberta went on to murder one person.
How about the latest? I have 18 names here, Mr. Speaker. My time is short. How about Dean Cyr? That is a name we have all read in the papers just recently. While out on parole in the province of Alberta he murdered two more people.
A man who gunned down nine members of a Saskatchewan family and sentenced as Canada's first mass murderer has been released from Penetanguishene hospital although the public was not informed. Is this protection of the public?
Again I ask my colleagues in this House to put yourselves in the shoes of the victims of violence. Are these not frightening examples of how the justice system has failed victims of violence? These situations which I have outlined are only the thin edge of the wedge. They represent only a fraction of the cases where violent offenders are released from prison on day parole or temporary escorted and unescorted absences, who have committed violent crimes and Canadians feel powerless to do anything about it.
As a former Alberta crown prosecutor, Scott Newark, has noted, a list of offenders he recently compiled shows that in the last five years 19 offenders were found to have been responsible for 22 murders while on some form of parole. As Scott Newark noted, Canadians should be made aware of these incidents because he wants them to know that they are not the exception to the rule. They occur much more frequently. He wants Canadians to know that these are not cases of offenders falling through the cracks because if they were, these cracks are as wide as the Grand Canyon.
Under Bill C-330 I believe that Canadians can feel secure. Unlike Bill C-36 and Bill C-90, Bill C-330 does protect the public. It provides public protection and the rights of victims as its paramount objectives. Under my bill, victims of violence will have rights, rights not considerations.
The victims of violent crimes or their families or their spouses, if the person is deceased, must be consulted throughout the judicial process. It is not much to ask. When an offender is arrested, the victims must be notified of his or her release on bail. If the offender commits an act while out on bail, he or she will be incarcerated pending trial.
Victims of crime will be consulted all the way through the trial. They will be present at pre-trial hearings, where so often the plea bargaining process that Canadians hear about will be curtailed because the victim's statements must be taken into consideration and lesser charges will not be traded off to dispense with the case.
November 19, 1992

When the offenders are convicted, victims of crime must be notified of any change in incarceration of that inmate. Victims would be notified of the day on which an inmate was scheduled for parole, the days on which the inmate would be absent on escorted absence for rehabilitative reasons, and any escape of the offender.
With respect to unescorted or escorted temporary absences, for violent offenders convicted of sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, assault with a weapon, and murder, Bill C-330 would deny day passes and escorted or unescorted absences. Bill C-330 would keep those violent offenders in jail until they were eligible for full parole. If they wanted to be released on a day parole or on an escorted or unescorted temporary absence for humanitarian or rehabilitative or medical reasons, they could get it. But that decision would have to come directly from cabinet.
This is what we are talking about. We are talking about public protection and accountability. Members of the National Parole Board are seen as somehow isolated from the concerns of Canadians, and perhaps they are in many respects. Certainly we have many examples of that. This bill would make our elected cabinet responsible for releasing offenders and make the system accountable. Is that not what Canadians are crying out for today? They want accountability.
Bill C-330 would deny parole to offenders convicted of first degree murder. The law currently states that the remedy for persons convicted of first degree murder is life in prison with no chance of parole for 25 years. This bill would remove eligibility for parole. Life would mean life. For the thousands of victims in Canada who want real protection, life means life.
That may be harsh, and I know some members in this House would find that too tough. I have spoken to the Edwards family. I have consulted with them and I said, look, there may be members in the House of Commons who might not agree with you, and in fact may not allow

if you can imagine for a moment-this bill to go on to committee stage for a full and frank discussion, because of that particular motion. The Edwards family said fine, then tell them.
Private Members' Business
We go to committee stage and just maybe we can discuss it, and if it is too harsh then what we can do is not have life mean life, but maybe we can put forward the position that if an individual is convicted of three murders then that individual gets a 25 year sentence for each of the murders. In our current system, if I go out and murder someone, then another one, and another one, as happened to the Edwards family, I go to jail for one term of 25 years if convicted. So it was a freebie for me that I murdered her father. It was a freebie for me that I almost murdered Michelle. All these are freebies, because I will only go in for 25 years. Then I will be eligible for a reduction by parole to 15 years. I can apply.
Is there anyone among us here tonight who would say that we are not even prepared to discuss this issue at committee stage? I would like to seek the unanimous consent of this House that at the conclusion of this debate, at one minute to six, to move Bill C-330 to a legislative committee in the departmental envelope.
I thank you for that consideration, Mr. Speaker, and I thank my colleagues in the House of Commons for then-attention. I know they have received mail and petitions. I thank the victims of violence who participated in the process of this bill: the Edwards family and the Smith family who consulted with me and helped me structure this bill. I also thank the legal clerk of the House who helped me put this bill together. I thank all those people who took pen in hand, in all the communities across this country, not just Ontario, and put their signature to a petition that said: "Please, at least give us the opportunity to have the open discussion at committee stage".
