speakeroldname: Mrs. Monique B. Tardif (Parliamentary Secretary to Solicitor General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Solicitor General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, thank you for letting me speak today in the debate on Private Member's Bill C-330. It seems that the criminal justice system has held a place of prominence in the House in recent months. The Minister of Justice has sponsored legislative reform in the areas of sexual assault, gun control, young offenders, extradition, mental disorder, and sentencing. The Solicitor General has done his share in legislative reform with amendments to the Criminal Records Act and sweeping reform, indeed the complete replacement, of the Parole Act and the Penitentiary Act through Bill C-36 which has created a new Corrections and Conditional Release Act.
Far be it from me to say that any legislation, no matter how newly minted, is perfect for all situations. It is our duty as legislators to remain vigilant for changing circumstances that may require the reform of existing laws and we must be alert to inconsistencies and anomalies in our laws that may give rise to injustices. The private member's bill is a mechanism by which reparative measures can be suggested-and sometimes enacted. I need not remind hon. members that the persistence of the hon. member for Mississauga South in the matter of pardons had much influence on the recent initiative which revised the Criminal Records Act. I am a great believer in the importance of those items debated under Private Members' Business.
The bill before us, standing in the name of the hon. member for Hamilton West, seems to fit right in with the recent government reforms in the area of criminal justice.
I fear however that Bill C-330, an act to amend the Criminal Code and the Parole Act, asks us to reconsider items that could have been included in Bill C-36. Indeed, many of these points were reviewed extensively by witnesses and parliamentarians in the process of passing Bill C-36.
As all hon. members probably know, Bill C-330 was referred to the Standing Committee on Private Members' Business, where all parties are represented. Upon review, it was determined that since this bill did not have
unanimous support in the House of Commons, it would not be put to a vote at second reading.
I know that some tragic events in and around the constituency of Hamilton West have put tremendous pressure on the hon. member and on us all to find solutions to problems in the field of criminal justice.
The public reaction to recent deplorable and senseless crimes is quite understandable. Canadians' efforts to urge the government to make changes are commendable. However, I think that several of the amendments proposed in the bill are already in the new Corrections and Conditional Release Act, while some of the other proposed measures do less for victims than this legislation.
In the limited time available to me, I would like to show you how the government has already addressed many of the key issues in Bill C-330. I think that hon. members will then see that the bill before us as it is does not reflect the best interests of the Canadian public.
The new Corrections and Conditional Release Act came into force on November 1, 1992. It provides a comprehensive set of rules governing how a prison sentence is to be served and when and how release will take place.
This legislation makes it clear that public safety is the paramount consideration in all correctional decisionmaking and provides explicit criteria for correctional and conditional release decisions. The legislation provides authority and direction to correctional staff and officials and informs offenders of the nature of their obligations and rights, as well as the limitations on those rights.
It promotes more effective exchange of information concerning offenders between correctional authorities, the courts, the police and officials responsible for release. Of great importance is the specific authority it provides for the release of pertinent information about offenders to victims of crime. This is also a key feature of Bill C-330.
In fact, Mr. Speaker, the new law provides better protection to victims and involves them more in the correctional and conditional release process. Its provisions for use of victims' statements and for sharing information are not restricted to certain categories of offences or to certain decisions. Bill C-330 is restricted
November 19, 1992

in these respects, and would exclude certain victims from participating in these ways.
The new act allows for victim input at all points in the correctional process. Similarly, it allows victims of any criminal act, not just the few crimes listed in Bill C-330, to request specific information on offenders.
The CCRA goes even further, in that it permits the National Parole Board to increase public access to parole hearings by giving it the authority to decide who may attend them as an observer.
This will allow more members of the public, including victims, to attend hearings and will help open up the parole process, demystify it and promote accountability in parole decisions.
A number of elements in Bill C-330 are not compatible with the new act and therefore should not be supported. For example, Bill C-330 would restrict certain types of conditional release for certain violent offenders. Of course the government endorses the principle that violent offenders should be more closely scrutinized and more stringently dealt with than nonviolent offenders. That is at the heart of the CCRA. However, the government also recognizes that gradual, structured, controlled release of offenders is in the community's best interest. Eliminating certain types of conditional release for those offenders who most need a structured, controlled return to the community makes no sense to me.
We must remember that not only full-time release to the community is involved. We are also talking about short-term releases whereby offenders can obtain therapeutic treatment in the community when such treatment is not available in the institution.
Surely that type of release, where the offender does not pose a risk, is in the best interests of both the public and the offenders. Yet Bill C-330 would abolish that type of release for those offenders who need it most.
The bill also proposes that certain temporary absence passes be approved by cabinet rather than by the National Parole Board. The Solicitor General commissioned a comprehensive outside review of the temporary absence program as part of the reform of the correctional system. Nowhere in the report, which was written by a panel consisting of a lawyer, a former member of Parliament and a former police chief and which endorsed the temporary absence program subject to a number of
Private Members' Business
recommendations, did they recommend that authority for temporary absences be turned over to cabinet.
If a temporary absence program is to be effective, it must have decision-makers who are familiar with the individual offender's case, and it must be able to respond to situations where, for example, an offender requests a pass to attend the funeral of a family member being held within a day or two. Requiring such requests to go to cabinet would be extraordinarily cumbersome and completely counterproductive to the aims of the temporary absence program. If accountability for decision-making is the issue, I would suggest that there are better ways of achieving it.
The central objective of the CCRA is increased public protection and restoration of public confidence in the system. The problem of crime will always be with us, and the debate will continue as to how best to deal with convicted offenders, especially those convicted of violent offences. We must at all times remain attentive to public concerns about crime and criminal justice.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to be here this afternoon to make my contribution to this debate on Bill C-330, standing in the name of the hon. member for Hamilton West.
For a long time we have been dealing with a very serious and tragic problem in our society, and that is the increase in the number of violent crimes being committed day by day across this country. There is a very real fear that unless we adopt the appropriate measures, the criminal element within our society and our society itself will become more and more like our neighbours to the south.
At the outset of my brief remarks I want to remind the House that the Americans have gone the route that Bill C-330 to some extent wishes to go, the turn the lock and throw the key away approach to violent offenders.
If longer sentences or lifetime sentences would bring greater security to our neighbourhoods, I would support it. Also the United States would probably be the safest country in the world in which to live. Unfortunately, that is not what happens. There is no correlation between longer sentences and diminution in the number of violent crimes in society. Surely we have to look elsewhere for some of the solutions. I am suggesting that there are no solutions to this problem that will totally

November 19, 1992
Private Members' Business
eradicate violent crime. I know the hon. member appreciates that as well.
For example, this bill would completely eliminate parole for offenders convicted of first degree murder.
I know that many of these murders, in fact most of them, are heinous crimes, they are horrible crimes. The member knows that some of the perpetrators will never be let out. I am quite certain that Clifford Olson is there for the rest of his life. There are others like him in there.
Take for example the 12 who are out right now as a result of the 15-year judicial review. Not one of them has reoffended. We have people in this country today who were convicted of capital murder under the old system who have never reoffended. Indeed, if you take all the convicted murderers as a group in our prison population, when they are released they have the lowest recidivism rate of any group in our prison system.
I know that it almost sounds cruel to use these statistics and figures if we are dealing with an individual personal tragedy. Words, arguments, debate or laws cannot bring back loved ones. They cannot erase the horrible memory of that terrible, heinous crime and I am not suggesting for a moment that anything we do in this Chamber can accomplish that. I am asking and pleading for a reasonable objective approach when it comes to altering the laws with respect to violent criminals. I am convinced that violent criminals should be kept in jail much longer than they presently are. The one-third can now be increased to one-half of sentence.
I told the Solicitor General in the justice and solicitor general's committee that if he wanted to raise that to 75 per cent of the sentence, I would support him, provided that the government was prepared to improve the programs for these offenders when they were behind bars and provided the programs were made adequate for all of them.
You know what happens now. They get thrown into prison, they sit there and vegetate for about one-half, two-thirds or three-quarters of their sentence and then in the year before they are to be released they are zipped
through a program and out the door they go, not fully prepared for the street.
One of the basic tenets in our criminal justice system and in our prison system today is that history has proven it is safer for society to gradually release violent offenders and even some sexual offenders. They should gradually be released into society rather than keeping them there for five, eight or ten years and then throwing them out cold turkey on to the street without any preparation, without any training or rehabilitation programs and without any supervision.
When the warrant expires, they have done their time and they are out the door. Some of them are cunning enough to know that they do not want early parole. They would rather wait until termination of sentence so that they could go out without any supervision. That is the time to make sure you gate them and bring them back in. That is where I would like to see this bill become operative.
I am supporting this bill at second reading because I want it to go to a committee. I want it fully discussed because there are a lot of things wrong with our criminal justice system today and there are a lot of things wrong with our present parole system which Bill C-36 incidentally, does not address. I sat through all those hearings and as far as I am concerned, it was largely a sham.
Let us take a look at some of the statistics on temporary escorted and unescorted leaves. The successful completion rate in this country of unescorted temporary absences is 99.28 per cent. This is not an exact science. We know that if we are going to have a system where they are gradually released into society, unfortunately and tragically, someone is going to reoffend.
It is not an exact science. We do not have a 100 per cent guarantee, but when the unescorted temporary absence success rate is 99.28 per cent that is pretty good. In fact, it is one of the best in the world.
Escorted temporary absences are 99.97 per cent successful. It takes only one to rape, murder, strangle and kill an innocent girl, a loved one, a mother or a father. It sickens the whole community, but I do not know how we square that with keeping them all behind bars for the entire sentence so they come on to the street totally unprepared. I suggest to you it could be worse. I
November 19, 1992

am not saying that it would be. I am saying it could be worse than these statistics would otherwise suggest.
There should be "no ETA for humanitarian or medical reasons unless approved by Governor in Council". Between 1975 and 1986, the National Parole Board released 52,484 inmates. I really do not know how a cabinet could handle that kind of workload. They would end up taking the advice of the National Parole Board anyway. As a practical measure I do not think it would work. It would be rubber stamped through the cabinet and they would be on parole anyway.
While I use that figure of 52,484 inmates who were paroled in those 11 or 12 years, only 63 of them where serving a sentence for capital murder, which would be similar to murder one today. Of those 63 who were serving a sentence for capital murder that were sentenced before 1976, only two were sent back because they had committed an offence against a person.
If we try to look at this as dispassionately as we can, we come to several conclusions. First, the system is not perfect. Second, the parole system is extremely effective and very successful when compared to other jurisdictions, for example in the United States or in Europe. It is not perfect but it is extremely good. Third, how do we get around the issue of gradual release into society if we are going to throw the key away and keep people in jail for the rest of their lives, particularly in the case of those convicted of first degree murder.
Sometimes even the worst human wretch in society is capable of reformation and rehabilitation. We have living examples of them today in our society, where they have been rehabilitated and have come back to live useful lives.
Could you imagine what prisons would be like if we had lifers in there with no hope of release ever? Could you imagine what life would be like for prison guards, for other inmates and for other people working in the prison environment? It would be an intolerable situation.
Private Members' Business
I look forward to further discussions on Bill C-330. I thank the member for Hamilton West for presenting this bill. I hope it will go to a committee so that we can give it a thorough airing.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity today to comment briefly on Bill C-330.
First of all, I would like to congratulate the hon. member for Hamilton West who introduced this private member's bill in the House. As you know, I seconded the motion for second reading, which does not mean I agree with all the provisions the bill contains. In fact, if that were the case, we could rid of the process we have here in Parliament-second reading, study in committee and third reading-and just fine tune the changes made in various bills during consideration in committee.
My point is that although a member may disagree with one or two sections of a bill, this is not sufficient reason to reject the entire text, at least not at the second reading stage.
At third reading, if members of this House are still convinced the bill was not satisfactorily improved in committee, the process will take its course.

That is not what is before us today. This is discussion in principle. This is second reading. The discussion in principle is on the topic whether or not violent crime victims and their families should be allowed a greater say. That is the fundamental principle behind it.
Yes, some provisions of the bill are perhaps harsh. I will get to those later. With this bill there would be an automatic provision for victims to provide an impact statement for their families. That is something we badly need.
The hon. member for Charlesbourg told us earlier that it was now possible in some cases for victims to provide this kind of impact statement. That may be true, but it is not automatic. It is optional, as a result of recent amendments to Bill C-36. With Bill C-330, if I am not

Private Members' Business
mistaken, this privilege would become a right. I think that symbolically this is very important.

The member for Brant spoke of the lock the door and throw away the key approach. I know he did not suggest that was exactly the purpose of the bill, but that concern does exist. Nowhere in this bill does it say criminals are not to be rehabilitated while they are incarcerated.
There is nothing in the bill which precludes that from happening, nor is there anything that precludes the rehabilitation of criminals right now, even though it is not done sufficiently in my view. Tb that extent, I share the view of the member for Brant that criminals are not adequately rehabilitated at the present time.
We do not have a bad record as a nation in that regard, but that does not mean to say it cannot be improved. We should do more.
On the other hand, the rights of the victim and the rights of the convicted criminal are on a pendulum and I believe at the present time that pendulum has swung quite a bit too far in the direction of those who have committed the crimes. The victims are neglected, or at least not being treated as they should.

That is why I welcome the opportunity to support this bill. I hope that later on all members will vote for the bill at second reading, not so that it can be rushed through the House and get Royal Assent and come into effect tomorrow morning-members opposite know better than that-but so that it can be referred to a parliamentary committee that will give the proposed legislation thorough consideration, amend the bill and improve it as all bills should be, especially government bills, which often need improving. It is certainly not unusual for a bill to require some changes at the committee stage.
Personally I think the section that says someone who has committed murder should never be allowed to leave prison is too harsh. However, I believe the present legislation is not strict enough. Of course there will be adjustments in committee, as the hon. member for Brant mentioned. By referring the bill to a parliamentary committee, we will have a chance to talk to a number of people who advise us and make recommendations.

In terms of whether or not cabinet approval should be sought for releases, I find it unusual that some would say cabinet approval would be a form of rubber stamp. Perhaps that is so, to a degree, but the accountability is still there.
I remind the House that right now, for instance, thousands upon thousands of people in this country are landed immigrants through the same process of Order in Council approvals. You see stacks of them in the Canada Gazette all the time. Why is that not just left to administration? Because there is a form of accountability there. When the system goes wrong we can ultimately, as the custodians of the rights of the people of this country, ask questions in this House. That is one of the reasons why that is there. The fact that cabinet ministers' staff advise them to make recommendations does not particularly bother me. I do not expect the minister to physically enter the penitentiary and start interviewing all the candidates before they can go to their mother-in-law's funeral or something. Obviously that is not going to happen.
I do think the level of accountability has to be increased, notwithstanding the fact ministers will likely have staff to assist them. That staff will probably end up being either the Parole Board or a similar instrument, but the accountability will be there and nowhere will people be able to say: "It is not my fault, the Parole Board acts independently".

I also wish to see prisoners gradually released into society and I think that the member for Hamilton West feels the same. In other words, those who are released must be better prepared when they come out of prison.
We also want the victims' rights and those of their families to be respected. I feel we have neglected the victims' rights over the last few years and even the last decades, and in saying this, I want in no way to put the blame on one minister or one person in particular. I just feel it is time we did something for the victims.
I ask all my colleagues here today to allow this bill to proceed, at least up to the committee stage, at which time we shall give our verdict.
November 19, 1992

Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege for me to speak this evening on Bill C-330, a private member's bill, an act to amend the Criminal Code and the Parole Act that was moved by the member for Hamilton West.
Numerous petitions were distributed around the country and here a Conservative member of Parliament is allowing a petition to go into his office that was forwarded to a Liberal member of Parliament. I can assure you that has only happened once, that I can think of, in my office.
Though we often disagree on many issues, when the member for Hamilton West first mentioned this issue to me there was an initial amount of support. The member has explained the benefits he sees in the legislation and there are many principles I can support in this bill.
I think this bill represents the many discussions that take place in this country in barber shops, coffee shops and variety stores when people are buying their newspapers. This is one of the issues they do talk about.
This bill does have some weaknesses. Regarding crimes of violence, for example, I think there is a need for a more comprehensive list of violent offences. I also think there is a need to more stringently define those measures rather than those that apply to non-violent offenders. We have to make that distinction.
I do not think the member for Hamilton West would object to having this discussion take place in a parliamentary committee. When it comes to victims' statements, I congratulate the member for clearly putting in the bill that the definition of a victim includes: "any relative of that person".
We should go further with the section relating to impact statements. It is important to expand the categories of offences for which victims' statements can be used. It is also important to expand when victim impact statements can be used for detention reviews. I think we should go even further and ensure that victims are given the right to attend the parole hearings. Those are the ways I think this particular provision can be strengthened. The member for Hamilton West may disagree with some of these views, but I think he would welcome an open discussion in a committee where not only other
Private Members' Business
MPs but witnesses can come forward, discuss their concerns and get victims' statements from those who are victims of violence offences.
The member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell talked about the releasing authority and the fact that it may require cabinet approval. I think that might be too restrictive, but again it is something that can and should be discussed in committee where we can discuss the views of the Parole Board or whoever makes the decisions to ensure that there is public safety. In many ways I think I would like to keep the politics out of those subjective decisions.
In the city of Cambridge, like the member for Hamilton West has indicated, there are many instances. I have a series of newspaper clippings that relate to a couple in Cambridge that are well respected in the community, Doug and Margaret Pollington. This is a Cambridge couple that have been battling their own life sentence since the day their son-in-law killed their 29-year-old daughter and two children aged five and six in 1976.
Since August 1, they have been playing a waiting game because the son-in-law becomes eligible to apply for a judicial review after serving only 15 years of his life sentence. The concern that the Pollingtons have is that there is no time limit for when the review must be applied for. Although the victims cannot currently make a statement or express their feelings about the review board, they must wait around for the prisoner to apply for a review.
That statement was recorded in the press before the passage of Bill C-36. Bill C-36 does allow victim impact statements. That legislation is too new to really make a valid comment on its effectiveness. The Pollingtons did recognize that indeed Bill C-36 could help them. After the passage of Bill C-36 there is a belief that maybe Bill C-36 could have gone further.
In this particular case Mr. Pollington admits that his main reason for getting involved with a petition on this legislation is because he wants to make sure that his own family is protected from the man who has already killed three members of his family. As he presented the petition around the city, he did not hide the fact that the clause stating that a life sentence for a person convicted of first degree murder should mean life and that for

November 19, 1992
Adjournment Debate
people convicted of first degree murder no day passes, escorted or unescorted, should be issued. He did not hide that particular fact.
Mr. Pollington and his wife appeared before Cambridge city council and received support for his petition. He went to Kitchener city council and also received the support of the council. Subsequently, he went to the regional council of Waterloo and also received the support of that council.
There were a few members of the regional council and city council who voted against it. Their reasons were the same reasons I would like to see it go to committee, so that there would be frank discussion. The people of Correctional Services for example could come forward would then explain and have an educated debate. Both sides would then understand where everyone is coming from. Councillors that did vote against it said they were hoping that when it comes forward there can be debate and we can hear from all sides on the issue.
Doug Pollington has also gone out to the high schools, not to solicit signatures for his petition but to discuss the Parole Act and specifically the victims' role, victims' statements and their importance. He has gone out to the schools. Hopefully the information that the kids are getting in their law classes will make them consider changing the law in the future. Again, he is not trying to recruit students into joining him or becoming involved with this petition, but he thinks it is important that they have an understanding of the effects the system does has on victims of crime.
He started out hoping to gather some 8,000 or optimistically 10,000 signatures on his petition. In the Cambridge area, 18,000 have signed his petition supporting Bill C-330.
What is happening here is that Mr. Pollington's petition is speaking for the people because he realizes how much the Cambridge community, like every other community, is upset and has concerns about the Canadian justice system.
I respect the role of the Standing Committee on House Management. I am tempted to stand here and say that I respect its judgment. However, I am suggesting that I disagree with its decision because it limits debate today.
I believe this is an issue that deserves discussion in committee because the general public want to have an
open discussion on this. I think the bill can be improved, but more important, the principles must be discussed. There is a need to openly discuss why the rules should be tightened up for allowing temporary absence from prison.
I hope the next time I have a chance to speak on this bill it will be in a parliamentary committee.

Mr. Speaker, given the reason we are elected is to serve our constituents, to provide for them the opportunity of a full and frank discussion and given the support I have from my colleagues in the Liberal Party, the New Democratic Party and my colleagues in the Conservative Party, I seek unanimous consent for the second reading motion on Bill C-330 to be put to a vote.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity tonight to expand a little bit on the question I posed to the minister of fisheries on the permanent quota transfer which I am not sure has commenced yet, but I have certainly seen an application for permanent quota transfers sent to people in my riding. At the time the minister answered that he was not
November 19, 1992

aware this was going on and said that he would ask his department to look into it.
A lot of people in my constituency would say that this is what the policy of this government has led to and that there were no alternatives for the fishermen and the fish processing companies in the area than to go to a permanent quota transfer.
What it does in my estimation is that where we had temporary transfer of quota between the fishermen and companies in the last two years we will now, in other words, have a permanent transfer. I have not been able to find out who actually controls the fish for 1991 or
1992.	That is just one area of concern I have. Do the companies control it now or do the fishermen control it?
It used to be that if a fishermen could go out to fish, the companies locally would be able to process that fish, sell it and the local economy would be very good. As you transfer the fish from the fishermen over to the companies, you are now going to have some companies that cannot pay so they will probably not be able to purchase that quota. Other companies will be able to pay or banks will be involved in purchasing that quota.
Basically, I can guarantee that most of the fishermen will not be able to individually purchase a share of that quota. It will have to be a company. A bank will recognize that companies have assets and this will become one of its assets.
Where is the fish going to be processed and where is the company going to end up if it gets into difficulty? Will it end up a company in Newfoundland catching fish in the southwestern part of Nova Scotia, or a company coming and catching the fish in a part of southwestern Nova Scotia and bringing it back to Quebec to be processed if our companies get into trouble in the future. It has happened repeatedly on the east coast that companies have got into trouble. Look at National Sea, Nickerson's, and the companies in Newfoundland.
I also want to say there is another aspect to this. I do not think the government or the department of fisheries will ever be able to manage or control stocks. As most of
Adjournment Debate
the people in this House know, since 1988 one of the first things I asked was to have an in depth evaluation of the stocks in Scotia-Fundy, particularly in the Bay of Fundy, 4VWX, evaluated so we knew the condition of the stocks. They have ndf'done that, they continue not to do it, and yet now, with these individual transferable quotas to fishermen and to companies, we have a fishery that goes on year round. As long as you can prove you have access to some quota you are entitled to be out there.
The fishery is going to be fished out by somebody. I know some fishermen who cannot afford the penalties and who will only fish four months. They see a boat out there that has less individual quota than they do and is fishing year round. Where is the management? Where is the enforcement? There has to be a very real concern.
I hope tonight I am going to have an answer from the parliamentary secretary as to why the minister is going that way and why he is allowing the fishery to leave. I see it happening in the future. I see it happening even now, companies not processing groundfish. It will just be processed in certain areas and maybe even leave our area.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise this evening to refresh the House's memory on the question, and what I believe were the inadequate answers given to my questions regarding the Westray mining disaster.
The questions were raised last May 22, and the disaster of course took place on May 9 of this year.
I just preface my remarks by quoting the last verse of a miner's lament, a rather well-known one called Dark as a Dungeon.
I think when I die and the ages do roll My body will harden and turn into coal. As I look through the door of my heavenly home I will pity the miner adigging my bone.
A lot of miners in Nova Scotia, around Pictou County and throughout the country are simply not satisfied and their bones will not rest until they get some clear answers from this government.
Why did the federal government, which does not normally make major investments in mining operations, take a risk not only with public money but with the lives of Nova Scotia miners in this operation? The government suggested it had every reason to believe and understand it would be a very high risk operation. Why did it not take extra measures to ensure that the Government of Nova Scotia and the agencies directly responsible for mine safety were doing more than the normal routine run of the mill job to ensure the safety of the people who would be working in that operation. This mine likely would not have opened without the major intervention of the Prime Minister and ministers of the Crown, and would not have happened without the federal money that was later expended.
In my question on May 221 pointed out that according to the engineering consultants for the Bank of Nova Scotia, the construction of the Westray coal mine was one of the most rapid they had ever seen. It is extremely fast to achieve an underground mine in 10 months; normally you are talking years instead of months.
That information was available to the government. Other information as explained by the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources was available to the government. In spite of that, the construction of the mine went ahead.
Since then we have had the Nova Scotia inquiries cancelled; we have had charges laid. It is possible still for the federal government to answer the legitimate needs of these miners and their families and launch their own federal inquiry quite in keeping with the ruling given by the Chief Justice of the Nova Scotia Supreme Court in dealing with why this operation was allowed to go ahead with massive infusions of federal money, in spite of the warnings.
That is what those mining families want to know. That is what this House has a right to know. Whether it is a public inquiry or a committee of this House, those families deserve answers and we intend to keep pursuing this government until those answers are forthcoming.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Westray mine disaster was a sad day, not just for the people in that particular area of Nova Scotia but for all Canadians. The hon. member knows the federal government does not have jurisdiction in the area of occupational health and safety. This is truly the responsibility of the provincial government.
Notwithstanding this fact, the Government of Canada took a variety of measures consistent with our role as financial guarantors to ensure that the project was technically viable.
The initial environmental assessment, the Acres report, pointed out the key health and safety concerns associated with coal mines and the methods that the company was putting into place to overcome these concerns. All concerns, including those pointed out by the Associated Mining Consultants Inc., were deemed to be correctable with known technology. The CANMET review spoke briefly of mine ventilation and spontaneous combustion risk and concluded that in spite of these
November 19, 1992

technical uncertainties, the proposal had no major technical barriers.
Westray was required to comply with all appropriate coal mining regulations in Nova Scotia, including those dealing with mine ventilation and spontaneous combustion matters and regular provincial mine inspections were carried out.
We put in place steps to ensure the company was in full compliance with the provincial regulatory standards on health and safety. This was monitored on a monthly basis by an independent mining consultant. All of these facts were taken into consideration before the federal government made the decision to fund the project.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party

Mr. Speaker, on several occasions since May 8, 1992, I have raised in this House the issue of the economy of Montreal and its unacceptably high level of unemployment.
I asked the government to explain why it continually refuses to participate in an infrastructure repair program to stimulate job creation in the greater Montreal area.
The idea of this program was put forward by the Liberal leader and supported by the mayor of Montreal and by the Quebec government. The only thing missing is the federal government's participation.
We Liberals believe that a job creation program of this magnitude is necessary for Montreal. When I asked my question on May 8, the unemployment rate stood at 12.9 per cent. Since then there has been no improvement. In fact, the situation has worsened.
Let us just look at the past year. According to Statistics Canada, there were 186,000 officially unemployed people in greater Montreal. That figure does not take into account those who have simply given up looking for a job because they are completely demoralized. Today there are over 204,000 unemployed people in the region. This, in my opinion, is far from an improvement.
Adjournment Debate
According to a report prepared by the economic studies service of the Mouvement Desjardins, the Montreal region has lost no less than 60,000 jobs since the fall of 1990. During that period, 17,000 workers lost their jobs in manufacturing, 10,000 in retailing, 9,000 in the financial sector, and the list goes on and on.
The President of the Treasury Board would have us believe that his government does a lot more for the Montreal region. If that is the case, why is the region economy deteriorating so much? The average rate of unemployment now stands at 16 per cent, and in the east end of the city it is as high as 25 per cent.
The minister refers to the aeronautical and pharmaceutical industries. I recognize that these are important and make a great contribution to the economy of Canada and of Montreal, but they do nothing for those workers who have lost their jobs in construction or manufacturing.
According to the Commission de la construction du Quebec, the unemployment rate in that industry is almost 50 per cent for the province, and more than half of the workers affected are in the Montreal area.
We Liberals believe that a program to modernize our infrastructure would greatly help get the construction industry and the economy in general back on track. So even if the aeronautical industry benefits some sectors of the economy, it would be irresponsible to think that it is the solution to all our unemployment problems. As well, it would be irresponsible to neglect those individuals who have lost their jobs in manufacturing or construction. An infrastructure program would help those people directly.
On May 8 and again today I asked the government to explain why it continues to refuse to immediately implement this infrastructure program that would get the economy going. We are well aware that if you get the construction industry going, the rest of the economy will follow. We could put people to work and these people will spend and pay taxes. Thus, the government will also get some return on these important investments for the economy and the social fabric of our country.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to remind the hon. member that, in spite of the particularly gloomy picture he has just drawn of that area, Montreal can nevertheless rely today on a very modem manufacturing sector. This sector has progressed markedly, especially over the past decade.
Take for instance the aircraft industry, where 40,000 jobs were created in the Montreal area during that period. There is also the electrical and electronic products sector and that of machinery, chemical products, plastics and rubber, as well as the petroleum and printing industries. All these sectors have been extremely productive in the Montreal area.
All these sectors are growing rapidly and provide secure, well-paid, new jobs in the metropolitan area as well as new technologies.
However, it is obvious that what we need most in Montreal right now is to broaden this modern and promising manufacturing base and to broaden it at least enough to offset the job losses up until now as well as those anticipated in waning traditional industries.
Therefore, our role in government is to support this manufacturing base as part of a concerted effort, with a
consistent development strategy relying on the Montreal's strengths.
As we know, two programs have been implemented in Montreal recently, the IRPEEM and the IRPSWM, that the hon. member is very familiar with. These have helped support major investments as well as creating thousands of jobs in the area.
Mr. Speaker, I want to reassure the hon. member for Saint-Leonard that government has indeed taken the action he is requesting concerning the Montreal area. Also, government is planning further action, in consultation with the business community, the municipalities and the provincial governments, to ensure that Montreal remains a major player not only in the economic development of Quebec but also in that of the whole country. I am convinced that his party will support the Montreal area development initiatives we will be putting forward.
